sources.full: Grim Press Karthax the Living Tower

adventure.name: Grim Press Karthax the Living Tower

entries.name: Background
entries: The generation prior to the eruption of hostilities that marked the beginning of the Great Cataclysm was largely one of enlightenment. By this time, many mortals had been educated in the ways of art, literature, and magic. Universities and libraries were home to countless learned beings of all races who gathered in peace to debate religion and philosophy. The mortal races, by and large, were at peace, unified within the knowledge that beings far greater than themselves clearly wanted the mortal races to flourish under their benevolent gaze.

During this time, three sisters were born to a family of modest means. Despite their common upbringing, the trio were wildly different and yet tightly bound together in sisterhood that seemed unbreakable. Kyreen, the eldest, was disciplined, studious, and of even temperament. The youngest, Faradel, was impulsive, arrogant, and aggressive, and particularly competitive with her sisters. The middle sister, Avilnar, was aloof and disinterested in the ways of the world, yet a mischief-maker extraordinaire.

From a young age, the three sisters showed a natural aptitude and draw toward the arcane, and thus were attended to by the finest tutors and scholars their parents could provide. They were educated in all areas of the arts — literature, poetry, theater, history, debate, and magic. Yet where their hearts truly lay was in philosophy and religion and the deep interconnection of these topics with the Eld Gods. The sisters spent countless hours debating their will.

Faradel favored the argument that the weak should be ruled by the strong, and that law and order would naturally fall into place based on the strength of the prevailing chaos of nature. Kyreen agreed that the strong should prevail but the will of the Eld Gods superseded natural law; thus their Order must be obeyed at all times. Avilnar deeply enjoyed antagonizing the two opposing views, and her views often seemed (and were) fickle and chaotic.

Seeing these three argue the finer points of the Great Debate caused several of the Nine Eld Gods to take great interest in them. The Eld Gods began to weave their influence over the minds of the three, subtly affecting their thoughts, for the Eld Gods sensed the three sisters could become valuable servants to spread their word to other mortals. Over time, the Eld Gods' influence poisoned their minds, twisting the sisters' lively debate into furious arguments, pitting them against each other.
By the time the Great Cataclysm erupted, the three were so opposed that any bond of sisterhood had long disintegrated, and they joined their patrons to wage war upon each other.

When the ashes settled and Order prevailed, Kyreen was tasked with hunting down Faradel and Avilnar, who in turn sought vengeance against each other. Faradel, injured in one encounter, entered The Living Tower in exchange for sanctuary, not knowing her sisters would enter in pursuit of each other. Known as the Sisters of the Cataclysm, they have been bound in an endless hunt for each other within The Living Tower.

entries.name: Author's Vision
entries: While they perceive that only a few days have passed since they entered The Living Tower, Kyreen, Faradel, and Avilnar have in fact been pursuing each other on a single floor since they entered millennia ago. They have been engaged in an endless hunt for each other, each emerging victorious over another many times over the centuries. To maintain their burning hatred for one another, each time a victor emerges from their unending hunt Karthax wipes their memories, resurrects the fallen, and allows the hunt to begin once again. Karthax has also blocked their memories with respect to their patrons — when questioned about the Eld Gods they will pause, stare blankly for a moment, then proceed as though the question was never asked.
All three possess information and lore about the Great Cataclysm, though none remember the specifics of the Eld Gods who were their patrons.

Each of the sisters, if encountered, will engage with the visitors to this floor: Kyreen attempting to forcibly lead, Faradel offering a choice (aid her or die), and only Avilnar will allow the characters to make up their own minds without fear of retribution.
Once the characters have aligned themselves with one of the three, as a GM, we recommend making an initiative and beginning the hunt for the other sisters — moving the other forces accordingly.

entries.name: Kyreen, Hammer of Order
entries: The eldest of the three sisters of the Cataclysm, Kyreen is disciplined and intelligent, yet rigid in thought and lacks flexibility to see other perspectives. While debating her sisters and later hunting them down, this proved both an advantage and a potential weakness, in that her single-minded determination made her a relentless foe in combat but left her vulnerable to the unpredictable tendencies of her sisters and their tactics.

A particularly pious individual, Kyreen was in the midst of deeply examining the origins of the Eld Gods when war broke out and was convinced in the requirement for strict laws, predetermined in the Eld God's boundless wisdom, that would maintain justice for all mortal races and ensure peace. Kyreen thus also devoted herself to many hours of meditation and prayer, and through her piety has access to powerful magic to both aid others and bring divine justice to the forces of chaos.

During the Great Cataclysm, her patron presented her with an enchanted warhammer that glows with radiant power whenever creatures of a chaotic nature are near, which assisted Kyreen in hunting down and exterminating countless foes during the Cataclysm.

Clad in a heavy suit of plate, Kyreen made for a fearsome sight at the vanguard of several of the bloodiest battles of the Great Cataclysm and became revered as a leader by her allies and reviled by opposing forces.

Lawful mortal warriors, priests, clerics, and paladins were drawn to Kyreen while the forces of Order were gathering. Her followers were blindly faithful and loyal to her, obeying Kyreen's every command regardless of impact to others.

After the Great Cataclysm, Kyreen was tasked with hunting down and exterminating the remaining forces aligned with chaos and free will; thus she led an elite cadre of hunters to pursue these remnants and eventually her own sisters. Slowly, this force was whittled down to just her, the last of the sisters to enter The Living Tower — exchanging her presence within for the opportunity to at last confront her sisters.

{@b Roleplaying Kyreen.} Her sisters would have described Kyreen as pious, elegant, single-minded, and inflexible before they came to hate one another. Now they would describe her as a self-righteous fool blinded by an outdated and altruistic concept of what the world should be as opposed to what it is. Kyreen speaks boldly and confidently and comes across as a competent and confident leader. She leads through strength, however she views leadership through force and does not tolerate subordinates or other beings questioning her thoughts, actions, and tactics.
Kyreen is particularly suspicious of creatures of a chaotic alignment, and mistrusts them as she is unable to predict what actions such creatures might take.

She may nonetheless ally with such beings, though only for so long as Kyreen can tolerate what she perceives as their self-centered motivations. Eventually, though, all must obey her commands and subject themselves to her.
Kyreen can be articulated as follows:

items: - When describing how she entered The Living Tower:  "{@i I was pursuing my vile sisters. They must be brought to justice for their crimes — order has prevailed!}"

- When describing Faradel (spitting on the floor):  "{@i Pah! That vile creature knows not what is coming for her. She weaves her twisted magic creating abominations that threaten us all. She must be eliminated!}"

- When describing Avilnar:  "{@i Oh my foolhardy little sister...she never was of sound mind. This left it to be twisted by whatever creature she served. The atrocities she has committed in their name must be avenged! She must be exterminated!}"

- When interacting with characters of a lawful alignment: *"You! If you be followers of the law you will join me in bringing justice to my sisters. Only then can we rebuild the world!" and "I will not tolerate questioning from you — I command, you obey; that is the law in my presence!"

- When interacting with characters of a chaotic alignment (suspiciously): "I will be clear - I do not trust you. There will come a time when you will choose to submit to the law or you will become my enemy."

entries: Kyreen will ally herself with chaotic-aligned characters only until her other sisters have been vanquished, at which point she will turn on and attack such characters exclusively, ignoring lawful-aligned allies — these she will view as poor, misguided souls who will be released from the twisted influence of chaos once it has been eliminated.
While she does not remember specific details about her patron (her memory being blocked by Karthax), Kyreen will describe the following about the Great Cataclysm:

items: - The time before the Great Cataclysm was peaceful. Enlightened. All races were welcome, tolerated, and embraced. Kyreen misses her time in the great libraries of the world.

- The Great Debate led into the Great Cataclysm by the actions of an unknown, would-be assassin who struck at one of the Eld Gods. This never would have happened if Order had been enforced on the mortal races.
- Clearly the forces of chaos unleashed fire and flood and ripped the world apart. Only such beings could possibly release such chaotic forces without regard for the sanctity of life.
- The Gods of Order have prevailed. Justice, might, and law now rule - chaos has been tamed, the world will be soothed and brought to a place of peace.

entries.name: Faradel, Scourge of the Living
entries: As the youngest sister of three, Faradel always felt the need to keep up with her older sisters. In particular, she always admired Kyreen, whose intelligence and calm demeanor always seemed to keep Faradel's impulsive and tempestuous nature in check. From childhood onward Faradel was brash, quick to anger, and seldom hesitated to speak her mind where others might pause and debate if a wiser course of action might be in order. She was insatiably curious, and her mind, while it was not nearly as structured or disciplined as Kyreen's allowed her to see less conventional paths forward. This served her particularly well during the battles of the Great Cataclysm, where forces under her command would employ unorthodox tactics and often score decisive victories against otherwise superior forces.

While Kyreen was pious and noble, Faradel believed that morals and rules would ultimately be the downfall of free will — the end would ultimately justify the means. In her view, the Eld Gods had allowed and encouraged the mortal races to explore their own, which was a clear license for power to rule and be overthrown in its own time by those more cunning or worthy.

It was her numerous victories that ultimately led to her downfall, however. Becoming emboldened by her successes in battle, Faradel became more arrogant, more convinced in her superiority and that none could match her tactically. That is, until she was routed by an equally unorthodox ambush by Avilnar, who took advantage of a particularly brutal battle between forces led by Kyreen and Faradel — their forces both decimated by wave after wave of chaotic energies unleashed by Alvinar's band of corsairs.

In her desperation, her forces weakened, demoralized, and near complete collapse, Faradel unleashed magic uncovered in ancient tomes long forgotten in the depths of one of the many monasteries she studied in. Whispering words of great power, she summoned forth the souls of the slain and offered them the opportunity to return to the world of the living once again. To the horror of the pitiful survivors on the field of battle, the dead walked the earth once more. Legions of her soldiers rose, along with a fewer number of Kyreen's and Alvinar's forces, who fled in the face of a renewed onslaught. This battle finally drew Faradel completely into darkness, warping and disfiguring her once comely figure into a twisted visage that matched her now completely blackened heart.
Creatures whose souls are tainted by darkness were drawn to Faradel - magi thirsting for knowledge, mortals seeking unending life, worshippers of demons, and other such beings.

Eventually a great final battle rained holy fire upon the Faradel's legions and her forces were exterminated. Faradel fled, seeking to recoup her losses and amass another freshly risen army. Relentlessly pursued by Kyreen to prevent such an occurrence, Faradel entered The Living Tower, bartering for time — a bargain Karthax was all too willing to accept.
Faradel is one of the few mortals able to truly harness necromancy and yet still retain their sanity.  〄

{@b Roleplaying Faradel.} Before her descent into darkness, Faradel's sisters would have described her as impulsive, curious, and desperately competitive. Now they would characterize her as the embodiment of darkness, who ultimately would sacrifice countless lives in the relentless pursuit of victory. While both her and Kyreen lead their followers with an iron fist, Kyreen maintains respect through her leadership — while Faradel's fist is bladed and invokes desperate fear in her followers — living and dead alike. Faradel is arrogant and contemptuous toward creatures who have morals and adhere to rules — be it decrees from on high, societal laws, or personal code of conduct. Convinced of her own superiority, she is also impatient and impulsive.
Faradel can be portrayed as follows:

items: When describing how she entered The Living Tower:  "{@i Victory was all but assured, but Kyreen — damn her! Kyreen's forces and those of the damned gods she serves overwhelmed those fools and annihilated our forces. So I fled...hunted by my cursed sister. I entered, seeking refuge, a chance to regain my strength, but both Kyreen and Alvinar have entered too it would seem.....}"

When describing Kyreen (whose name leaves a vile taste on her tongue):  "{@i Pious, pompous fool! In all manner I am her better, but she will not accept the fundamental truth — that power cannot be maintained by order. Fear is the material the blade of power is forged from! Death shall greet her within these walls!}"
When describing Avilnar: *"Even I cannot predict my middle sister. She seems to care not at all...it all seems a game to her. Fool. Power is hers to take and she uses it but sparingly."
When interacting with characters of a lawful alignment: "Rule-followers. Have you ever had a free thought within that thick skull of yours?"*

When interacting with characters of a chaotic alignment:  "{@i You see it, do you not? Chaos, magic, time — they are all there to serve at our command! Join me, I will show you power beyond measure...}"

entries: Faradel will ally herself with lawful-aligned characters, playing on their sense of right or wrong, sense of justice, or moral code only so long as she can manipulate them, or until her sisters are vanquished — at which point she will turn on and attack such characters exclusively, ignoring chaotic-aligned allies, which she views as misguided kindred spirits.
Faradel does not remember specific details about her dark patron Eld God (her memory being blocked by Karthax). Faradel will describe the following about the Great Cataclysm:

items: The time before the Great Cataclysm was peaceful — ripe conditions for exploiting fools who feel bound to follow laws and rules.

The forces of Order sought to prevent the seeds of choice, chaos, and free will from taking root. It was ironic then that they chose to unleash such violent chaotic energies to prevent the inevitable rise of chaos.

Justice is an illusion — one that is decreed by the powerful and used to control others. Better to allow all to live for themselves, according to what they see fit, than to be ruled blindly by other creature's choices.

entries.name: Avilnar, Corsair of Chaos
entries: The middle of the three sisters, as a child Avilnar was always caught between her two sisters — disciplined, noble, virtuous Kyreen on one hand and impulsive, chaotic, and arrogant Faradel on the other. In Avilnar's view, both were bickering over trivial matters. The Eld Gods...debated over trivial matters. The only things that truly mattered were the actions of an individual in the moment, and each living creature was part of an interwoven web of singular choices carried out each day that created a grand masterpiece — the tapestry of life.

Avilnar spent hours on end observing her siblings and their constant competition, inserting a few well chosen phrases, contradictions, and controversies into Kyreen's and Faradel's sometimes heated arguments. Both Kyreen and Faradel found Avilnar's comments infuriating to say the least, for it seemed the middle sibling's perspectives were constantly changing and mutable, never consistent enough to hold any substance. It seemed every other statement delivered by Avilnar was so outlandish it couldn't possibly hold any merit, and was delivered in such a nonchalant way that the two bickering siblings could never quite tell if Avilnar meant what she said — or if she was just manipulating the others.

Avilnar took great delight in egging her siblings on, sometimes even merrily skipping away while leaving the others fuming at her — and each other. A keen observer of behavior, Avilnar mastered the ability to manipulate and antagonize others, bending them to her will sometimes for the sheer sake of doing so.

Her mind was particularly adept at understanding and manipulating the subtler forces of magic — those of enchantments, illusions, and transmutations. Manipulating the thoughts and senses of other beings was as effortless to Avilnar as summoning a flicker of flame was to an evoker — thus she delighted in casting subtle spells upon others, enticing them to perform outlandish acts to the bewilderment of those around her.

While she slept, Karthax planted visions in Avilnar's subconscious — hardening her to the inevitable conflict looming on the horizon. Avilnar's mind shifted from a once carefree, mischievous soul to one prepared for the grim realities of war.

When the Great Cataclysm erupted, despite both her siblings imploring Avilnar to join them, she declined, each earning their hatred in return. Where both Kyreen and Faradel rose to lead great armies against one another, Avilnar led a modest force of corsairs determined to ensure freedom for all. Her forces, vastly outnumbered, relied on their cunning - setting elaborate traps, misdirecting through carefully-wrought illusions and enchantments, and eliminating key targets from either side in an effort to ensure neither side gained advantage for any length of time.

All manner of mortals joined Avilnar's cause of their own volition, seeking neither power through force nor restricting the freedoms of others, but instead only the freedom to choose their own path — right or wrong be damned, they would make up their own minds. Thieves, assassins, warriors, mages, and free-minded folk of all races followed her.

Both Kyreen and Faradel grew frustrated with repeated attacks against their forces by Avilnar's corsairs — they were unpredictable as her comments during their debates. Both cursed their sister, who carried out, at times, ruthless and unsavory acts against each. In return, both sent forth many hunters attempting to eliminate the thorn in their sides, but each time the master manipulator, weaver of illusions and enchantments, would dance out of their grasp.

Once the Great Cataclysm had erupted and the forces of Order prevailed, she tracked Faradel to The Living Tower. Entering felt correct... as though she had sensed Karthax's presence before. She entered willingly, asking nothing for herself.

{@b Roleplaying Avilnar.} As a particularly astute observer of behavior, Avilnar knows well the importance of putting on a disguise to mask her true intentions. She comes across as highly disinterested, airy, aloof, and uncaring, and uses this to test potential visitors to this floor. Unlike her siblings, who (unbeknownst to them due to Karthax's blocking of their minds) slaughter visitors to this floor once they have served their purpose, Avilnar has woven illusions and enchantments to protect a newcomer to this floor — a warrior, Amaalik, whom she has cleverly disguised as a harmless creature.
Avilnar can be portrayed as follows:

items: When describing how she entered The Living Tower:  "{@i I was in pursuit, trying to stop yet more madness from befalling the world. I might not be sane but my sisters do not even recognize their folly. We were all fools debating but a game. Somehow I feel quite at home here.}"

When describing Kyreen:  "{@i The poor, rigid thinker is so blinded by her rules she cannot see that in her quest for good she created great evil in return. Her blindness allows her to be so easily manipulated. Predictable as always she is — rules and order, blah blah blah.}"

When describing Faradel (shuddering):  "{@i Kyreen might be a blind fool who couldn't think herself out of a room with a single door, but Faradel — in her pursuit for power, she will stop at nothing and unleash all manner of monstrosities upon the world — she is beyond redemption.}"

When interacting with any character, Avilnar will be suspicious about their motives, questioning their character allowing their actions to speak for themselves. Should their actions suggest a tendency toward controlling others she will ruefully dispatch them once her sisters have been vanquished; should they be of sound mind and respectful of the choices of others, she will encourage this tendency as The Living Tower teleports the visitors away.

entries: Avilnar is the only sister who will allow visitors to leave this floor unscathed as noted above. She senses that the pursuit of her sisters and the events on this floor have happened time and again, and a strong sense of deja vu lingers with her. She does remember the following details about the great cataclysm:

items: The time before the Great Cataclysm was care-free — she enjoyed tormenting her sisters and their incessant need to argue. She wonders if her manipulations and teasing twisted her sisters along their paths.
Neither order nor chaos matter. Free will for the mortal races is all that matters — the ability to choose for oneself.

entries: Avilnar bears the {@item Mask of Pretense|gp_karthax}, a powerful magical artifact that allows the creature who wears it to appear different in the eyes of whomever they encounter. This item has allowed Avilnar to escape multiple difficult situations, both before and during the Great Cataclysm.

entries.name: Mask of Pretense
entries: {@i Wondrous Item, rare (requires attunement)}

This masquerade mask has 3 charges. It regains 1 charge each day at dawn. While wearing the mask, you can use your reaction to expend 1 charge, changing your appearance to beguile one creature of your choice that you can see within 60 feet of you. The form you take is determined by rolling on the {@table Mask of Pretense Forms|gp_karthax} table, which is plucked from the target's memories.

entries.name: Amaalik (aka Flipper)
entries: Amaalik hails from a small fishing village located far to the north within a barren arctic region. For generations, his family has contentedly fished the frigid waters, eking out a modest living and on occasion setting forth with his parents and brother to trade seal furs, bone carvings, and fish for necessities such as salt, sugar, iron cookware, and weapons.

Constantly in the shadows of his more clever brother (whom Aamalik felt was favored by his parents) and spending his days fishing, Amaalik tired of his mundane existence and set forth to do something few in his village could conceive: to find a new path.

Having never received a formal education, Aamalik was often looked upon with curiosity by others during his travels. As his social engagements were limited to the village in which he grew up, where there was little time for idle chit chat or frivolities, Aamalik's personality could be described as abrasive and abrupt. Feeling an acute need to prove himself more than just a humble fisherman, Amaalik is a strong, if untrained, fighter, courageous and inquisitive. It was this curiosity that led him to The Living Tower, which offered him the opportunity to be viewed as more than just a humble fisherman in exchange for entrance.

Through brute strength more than cunning, Amaalik made his way to this floor. While other visitors often find themselves ensnared by Kyreen and Faradel's commanding presences (inevitably leading to their demise), Amaalik was fortunate in that he encountered Avilnar first. Seeing their great potential as an ally, Avilnar offered to disguise the warrior in a seemingly benign form — that of an enormous penguin — to protect him from her sisters' endless conflict.

Dubbed "Flipper" by Avilnar, he has so far survived this floor while witnessing the three sisters hunt each other several times -— each time being raised from the dead and restored by Karthax to begin their hunt once again.

{@b Roleplaying Amaalik (Flipper).} As a large penguin, Flipper moves somewhat awkwardly, and has a high-pitched, abrasive voice. He is strong-willed, stubborn, courageous, and protective of Avilnar, but also peaceful and gentle by nature — only attacking those he deems to be a physical threat. He speaks in short, blunt sentences and can come across as rude or insensitive due to his lack of experience outside his fishing village.
Despite the illusions concealing his true nature, Flipper retains the stout heart of a true warrior.  〄
Flipper can be portrayed as follows:

items: When describing Kyreen:  "{@i She's strong and stubborn. Always barking commands. I don't like her.}"
When describing Faradel (shuddering):  "{@i That one scares me. Capable of anything. Brings scary things with her.}"
When describing Avilnar (waving his flippers):  "{@i She's more than she seems. Cares a lot. But odd. Not sure I trust her, but she protects me by hiding me like this.}"

When describing events on this floor:  "{@i They're always hunting and killing each other. Each time I see them rise. Wound close. They shake their heads. Wander back through the maze. Then it begins again. I've seen many people die because of each of them.}"

entries.name: 1. Teleportation Glyph

entries: The now familiar arcane magics that lifted you away from the previous floor whine incessantly around you, lowering both in pitch and in volume as you collapse to a marble floor.

Collecting your senses you gaze about. The floor beneath you is pure blue-white marble, polished to a fine sheen. Unlike on previous floors, the teleportation glyph beneath you retains a low hum, as though nearly...contented. As though the magical energies within the glyph feel...at home in the pure marble.

As you look around, to your astonishment you behold three separate and unique routes out of this room. In one direction, a maze of thick brambles awaits you, vines twisting and writhing as though sentient. In another direction, what appears to be sand awaits you. The final direction appears to resemble a northern forest, frost covering foliage.

Were you not exploring a magical tower constructed by a being of immense power that somehow managed to construct unique environments on each floor for the denizens therein, you might be shocked by this. But, here you are.

This floor has been enchanted with an elaborate set of illusions by Karthax as well as by Avilnar per the {@i mirage arcane} spell. The illusions in each section can be identified as such by a {@b {@dc 19} Intelligence (Arcana)} check made with disadvantage if the adventurer is not proficient in this skill. If identified, the illusions may be dispelled with a successful DC 19 {@i dispel magic} spell, revealing the true nature of this environment: a maze constructed of the pure blue-white marble found in the room containing the teleportation glyph.
In addition to this, there are a number of illusory creatures within this floor, per the {@i phantasmal killer} spell. Each will dissipate once triggered, and be reset after 3 rounds.

entries.name: 2. Bramble Maze

entries: Stepping into a thick tangle of what you recognize as yew and honeysuckle, you are shocked to see the tendrils of vegetation reaching for you, following your every move. In some places the plants are so overgrown you have to force yourself through.
If the adventurers use a fire-based spell or cut their way through the vegetation with a slashing weapon, the illusory vines will attack the offending character. Read or paraphrase the following:

The vines and leaves that have followed you unleash a piercing sound as though a cry of pain. Before you can react other than to clasp your hands over your ears, a number of thorny vines whip about your limbs, their brambles digging into your exposed flesh.

The illusory vines will restrain the offending creature. A creature restrained by the plants can use their action to make a {@b {@dc 15} Strength} check to break free. Each round a creature is restrained, they take 3 (1d6) bludgeoning damage from being constricted by the vines as well as 2 (1d4) psychic damage from the illusory, thorny brambles upon them. The vines can also be cut, each taking 1 slashing damage (4 vines are used to restrain each of a creature's limbs).

Once triggered, the walls and floors of this section of the maze become filled with needle-sharp thorns. A creature takes 2 (1d4) piercing damage every 10 feet it moves, and the terrain is considered difficult to move through.

entries.name: 3. Sand Maze

entries: Your first step upon the sand reminds you of stepping into a desert. The temperature immediately becomes sweltering, and even through the thick soles of your traveler's boots you can feel the heat of the sand beneath. You immediately begin to sweat.

There are two illusory sand pits within this section — if a character is sucked into the center, they are teleported back to the teleportation glyph and take 9 (2d8) psychic damage. If a creature is within 5 feet of the center of the pit, they must make a successful {@b {@dc 15} Strength} saving throw to avoid being sucked in; at 10 feet the DC is 13, and at 15 feet the DC is 11.

On the other side of the larger sand pit, a hidden door leads to {@b Faradel's} catacomb — it can be noticed with a successful {@b {@dc 13} Intelligence (Investigation)} check or by an adventurer with a passive Perception of 14. The door is unlocked.

entries.name: 4. Northern Forest

entries: Stepping upon what appears to be moss, decaying leaves, and undergrowth of what you would otherwise think is a northern boreal forest, you are pleasantly surprised by the scent of crushed pine needles. The air immediately becomes cooler, and you can almost hear the chirp of woodland birds.
A great statue of a lion upon a bronze base greets you — almost as though a shrine in a forgotten forest had been transplanted into the tower. Leaves and fallen branches litter the floor.
If the adventurers approach to within 5 feet of the statue, read the following:
As you approach the lion statue, you swear you see its carved pupils dilate. Before you can reach it, the lion lunges forward, its gaping mouth threatening to crush your skull.

Just as its jaws clamp shut, you stumble backward - your companions gazing at you with puzzled expressions as you land on your rump. Heart pounding, you turn toward the lion - only to find it hasn't moved.
You swear though that its  eyes seem a bit more sleepy, as would a cat lounging in the sun with a full belly.

The creature affected by the phantasmal lion's lunge takes 4 (1d8) piercing damage (no saving throw). The statue can be disabled with a successful DC 15 {@i dispel magic} spell that causes the illusion to become inactive for 1 hour before being restored.

entries.name: 5. Jungle

entries: Your first steps into what appears to be a jungle environment are a drastic change from either the crisp air of the forest or the hot, bone dry air of the sandy areas of this floor.
The air is hot and humid, and the vegetation resembles that which one would find in a tropical jungle. Thick ferns and vines hanging from the ceiling of this floor obscure your vision.
Brushing them aside, you see a pair of massive, humanoid forms turn to you. With a howl of surprise and challenge, the pair charge at you.
After a moment, follow up with:
You are barely able to bring your weapon to bear against the muscular beasts charging at you. They leap at you, massive fists driven by densely muscled shoulders plunging toward your skull.
At the last moment, the creatures simply...vanish.

entries.name: 6. Scorpion Room

entries: Another hall filled with sand greets you.

As you step into a small, sand-filled chamber, the sifting of sand beneath your feet startles you. Gazing to either side, a number of massive, chitin-armored scorpions unburrow and skitter toward you, wickedly barbed tails raised to strike while their pincers open wide and reach toward you.

The first creature that enters this room must make a {@b {@dc 15} Wisdom} saving throw. On a failed save, they are frightened and will flee in a random direction at their maximum movement speed for 1d4 rounds. At the end of each of the creature's turns, it must succeed on another {@b {@dc 15} Wisdom} saving throw or take 22 (4d10) psychic damage. On a successful save, the spell ends.

entries.name: 7. Webbed Room

entries: Thick spider webs have been woven across this room; an unfortunate reminder of a floor you visited what seems like some time ago. This time, the web's inhabitants are nowhere to be seen - as far as your cautious gaze can tell.

A hidden door off this room leads to {@b Kyreen's} chamber, where the Hammer of Order is preparing to set forth to hunt down her sisters. The hidden door can be seen with a successful {@b {@dc 13} Intelligence (Investigation)} check or by an adventurer with a passive Perception of 14. The door to Kyreen's chamber is unlocked.

The webbing is magical: each creature that starts its turn in the room or that enters it must make a {@b {@dc 13} Dexterity} saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is restrained in the web, and remains restrained until it breaks free with a successful {@b {@dc 14} Strength} check. Small or smaller creatures make their Dexterity saving throw with advantage, but Strength checks to break free are made with disadvantage.

A second hidden door off this room leads to {@b Faradel's} catacomb, but is more difficult to notice, requiring a successful {@b {@dc 16} Intelligence (Investigation)} check or by an adventurer with a passive Perception of 17. This door is barred from the other side, but can be broken in with a successful {@b {@dc 18} Strength (Athletics)} check.
Yipping, drooling, howling humanoids... what a fun illusion Avilnar has cooked up — mainly for my enjoyment, I'm sure!  〄

entries.name: 8. Kyreen's Chamber
entries: Behind a hidden door in the webbed room, Kyreen, the Hammer of Order, prepares herself to hunt down and defeat her sisters. Each time the trio engage in battle, Karthax resurrects the vanquished and wipes the memory of all three, resulting in a hunt that has lasted many centuries.
When entering this room, read the following:

You open the hidden door gently, not knowing what may lie behind. The stonework is what one might expect in any ancient ruin - sturdy, showing signs of aging, and with lichens growing amidst the masonry. Surprisingly, a small, calm pool of clear blue water rests in the middle of the room, the stillness of the water disturbed only by the occasional petal of a cherry blossom that gently descends from the pair of small trees on either side of it.
You hear a firm female voice singing what sounds like a marching song in a soft voice.
The singing stops the moment you enter the room.

Turning to your left as you enter, you see a cushioned stone bench beneath a third blossoming cherry tree, flanked by two stone lions. Upon the bench sits a figure - a female warrior clad in glistening plate armor, inspecting the blunt face of a large warhammer. Still inspecting it, she addresses you:  "{@i We shall start with one simple question: whom do you serve?}"

With that, the warrior stands despite the mass of her armor and flourishes her hammer as though ensuring it has the perfect balance.  "{@i Make it quick, I know my sisters are soon to arrive as well.}"

Kyreen, being an individual who values obedience and commands unwavering loyalty in those she chooses to ally herself with, will immediately attempt to assume command of a group of adventurers that are unaccompanied by another of her sisters. She will not tolerate anything less than complete command, and any attempt to usurp her or question her authority will be challenged, even subdued through force to ensure submission to her will. She will regard lawful-aligned characters with respect, and chaotic-aligned characters with suspicion — even turning against them once her sisters have been defeated. Seeing the world as black or white as she does, she will insist neutral characters pick a side, voicing:
Now is not the time for neutrality. Pick a side - that of the law, else leave immediately.
Characters willing to follow and aid Kyreen will then be expected to join her in hunting down and defeating her sisters.
If joining Kyreen, once the characters agree to do so begin an initiative roll, and begin to move the other forces each turn (Faradel and her undead being one faction, Avilnar and Aamalik the other).
If the adventurers encounter Kyreen while in the company of one of her sisters, she will assume they are aiding them and shriek:
So my sister has found herself lapdogs to do her bidding! So be it, they too shall be met with the hammer of justice!

entries.name: 9. Avilnar and Flipper's Refuge
entries: Within the arctic environment of this floor, Avilnar and Amaalik have taken refuge - Avilnar hiding Flipper behind an illusory disguise. Amaalik has seen several occurrences of Avilnar leaving on her own before mysteriously being teleported back and having vicious wounds magically closed before his very eyes, but has been unable to convince Avilnar that this has occurred. As a result, Amaalik is insisting on accompanying Avilnar on her next excursion (which to her is just the first).
When entering this section of the floor, read or paraphrase the following:

The instant you step upon the icy floor of this section of the maze, you are blasted by a sudden chill of arctic air that constricts your chest. The floor and walls are glazed with a thick layer of ice.

Any creature that moves faster than half its maximum movement speed must succeed on a {@b {@dc 13} Dexterity} saving throw or be knocked prone. If a creature fails its save by 5 or more, they take 2 (1d4) bludgeoning damage from the fall and are stunned until the beginning of their next turn.

There are two snowbanks in corners of the maze in which a layer of snow has collected. A frigid pond in the center of this section of the maze also contains a large, ice-covered rock upon which Amaalik rests. As the adventurers explore this section, read the following:

A startlingly blue pool of water has collected in the center of the maze. In the center of the pool upon a snow-covered rock sits a highly unusual sight - that of a large, black and white human-sized feather-covered creature. Seemingly contented on their perch, the creature's eyes regard you with suspicion - and vice versa. After a moment, its beak opens, but you are startled by a second figure bursting from the corridor beyond, lunging into the pool and calling at you:  "{@i Keep back, I trust you not at all! Who sent you here! Where are those wretches I once called sisters?}"

Avilnar, while eccentric, is an individual who values freedom of choice and will listen intently to the adventurer's story. While she is suspicious of all, she will reserve judgment and allow an individual's actions to speak for themselves. Unlike her sisters, who will come to their own conclusions and attempt to coerce the adventurers to join her on her hunt, willingly shares all she knows. She will, however, be very mistrustful of any whose actions seem directed toward excessively controlling, or those who seem particularly pious and rigid in their beliefs.

Once the character's and Avilnar have shared their story, Avilnar — protective of Amaalik — may encourage the transfigured warrior to share their story as well. After a time, the two will set out. Read the following:

Having attentively listened to your story and shared hers - each of you asking some directed and pointed questions of the other - the leather-clad warrior stands and stretches before addressing you:  "{@i Well, my story you've heard. Amaalik seems to think I've done this before, this "fool's errand" as he calls it, but my duty is clear, and with a heavy heart I must hunt down my sisters. There can be no more blood on their hands; our family name has now drowned in it. Accompany me if you will - it is your choice to make. I would simply ask you to not get in my way.}"
With that, Avilnar sets forth, a grim look upon her face. The large penguin pauses for a moment, gazing at you, before waddling quickly behind her.
If joining Avilnar, once the characters choose to accompany her, make an initiative roll and begin to move the other forces each turn (Kyreen being one faction and Faradel and her undead the other).
If Avilnar and Amaalik encounter the adventurers in the company of one of the other sisters, read the following:
The leather-clad woman pauses for a moment, addressing her sister:  "{@i Sister...I am sorry for what has become of us. There is too much blood on your hands...this must stop, and stop now.}"

Pausing for a moment as daggers are drawn, she addresses you:  "{@i Whatever she said to get you to follow her, it is wrong. You have a choice: aid her and I will slay you as well, stand aside and you will live, aid me and I promise nothing but a choice after that.}"
With an intricate weaving of her hands and muttering of some spell, your senses begin to whirl and your mind clouds...
If the adventurers attack Avilnar, she will respond in kind, otherwise her attacks will be focused upon whatever sister faces her. Amaalik will behave similarly.
If the adventurers choose to aid Avilnar, the other sister will shriek in rage:
Betrayal! Ever my little sister the manipulator! So be it, you too shall meet the fate so many have met before you! Now, die!"

There is a blocked passageway leading to Faradel's catacombs near the frozen pool - it can be noticed with a successful {@b {@dc 18} Intelligence (Investigation)} check, and can be destroyed (AC 10, 25 hit points, immune to piercing and slashing damage, vulnerable to fire damage).

entries.name: 10. Faradel's Catacomb
entries: Faradel, Scourge of the Living, and her undead creations reside within a catacomb that has been contained by hidden doors accessible from the webbed room, the sand maze, and Avilnar and Flipper's refuge. Each time a victor among the three emerges, Karthax resurrects the vanquished and wipes the memory of all three, resulting in a never ending hunt. When entering this section, read or paraphrase the following:
Breaking through the hidden entrance, your first instinct is to immediately cover your mouth. The waft of advanced decay greets you. While not unfamiliar, the sudden stench catches you off guard.

The floor of this section of the maze is littered with bone fragments, shattered as though crushed underneath one's boot. The walls are perhaps the most horrid sight: limbs and skeletal remains - some with tattered bits of nearly mummified flesh or rotten clothing still affixed - have been arranged within the catacombs. Unlike other ossuaries and catacombs where skeletal remains are provided with an orderly and dignified final resting place, these appear to have been carelessly tossed about.
Each step underfoot results in the crunch and crush of yet more bone fragments, sounds that reverberate off the walls in the still, stinking air.

This section is inhabited by Faradel and her latest undead creation - a {@b stitchwork golem.} The stitchwork golem frequently moans, adding a sense of suspense to this section of the maze. As the characters explore, read the following:
A faint moan echoes off the catacomb walls, an unholy sound that causes the hairs on the back of your neck to stand on end. It may be coming from around the corner...or is that from behind you?
Once the adventurers turn around the corner leading to Faradel's experimentation chamber, read the following:

Rounding the bend, you are shocked to see what may be the source of the moans: a great humanoid creature, 10-feet tall, gazes at you with dull mis-colored eyes. Its legs and arms appear to have been elongated as though from multiple sets of human limbs, for each has an additional joint. Numerous seams are visible even from this distance, as though the hideous creature was stitched together as the result of some vile experiment.

Behind the creature, a pair of flickering sconces cast eerie shadows upon the catacomb walls, flanking a table upon which a number of bloody surgical devices, as well as a grimoire, have been neatly arranged.

A silent stone statue - one that appears quite familiar, for it has the head of a leopard - watches over the scene. Behind the table, a figure cloaked in black casts off her cowl, revealing a young woman's features. One might view her as attractive, except for the icy gaze she regards you with.

After several tense moments of intense scrutiny, she addresses you in a soft, sickly sweet tone:  "{@i Pray tell, how did you come to my sanctum? I had asked for a bit of time - it seems Karthax only chose to give me but a little.}"

Faradel, believing as she does in power and force being tools to be used to enforce the will of the might, will attempt to coerce the adventurers into aiding her. She has a particular disdain for lawful-aligned creatures, whom she will sneer at and mock as rule followers. Such disdain, while thinly veiled, is nonetheless held in check provided she can entice or force such beings to follow her and do her bidding. Faradel is much more interested in chaotic-aligned characters, whom she views as more like minded — and potentially easier to entice and manipulate.

Faradel will show little interest in the characters, other than enlisting their aid — she will offer to share the secrets in her grimoire (which contains the {@i animate dead, banishment, bestow curse, blight, blindness/deafness, create undead, dominate person, eyebite, fear, protection from evil and good, ray of enfeeblement,} and {@i vampiric touch} spells) with those who would aid her — a ruse of course, for she would never allow another to potentially gain sufficient power to challenge her.
After a short engagement, she will set off to hunt down her sisters:
"{@i It is time. My new creation is ready, and I have more than this little trick up my sleeve. You shall accompany me - or, you can die here and now. Your choice.}"
If the characters choose to accompany Faradel, begin an initiative roll, and begin to move the other forces each turn (Kyreen being one faction, Avilnar and Amaalik the other).

If the characters refuse, Faradel and the stitchwork golem will attack. Faradel will also summon four {@b risen warriors} and three {@b risen mages} from the skeletal remains in the catacomb as a lair action.

If the characters agree to accompany her, she will summon her minions and set forth on the hunt as well — but direct others ahead of herself that she may keep an eye on them and, should her quest be fulfilled, be able to immediately dispose of her former allies in short order. Faradel will also retain some of her more powerful spells in reserve for just such an occurrence.

entries.name: Completing This Floor
entries: This floor is completed once two of the three sisters have been defeated, or, if Kyreen or Faradel are the last standing, all three are defeated by the adventurers.
If the characters aid Avilnar and Amaalik, and they are victorious, they will bestow the {@b mask of pretense} upon the characters. Read the following:

Softly uttering a prayer as she gently closes her sister's now vacant eyes, Avilnar looks up at you through teary eyes:  "{@i Amaalik tells me this has happened before, and strangely enough, it feels like I have been here before. Take this mask - it has served me well, may it also aid you. It has kept me alive.}"
As she completes those words, she is levitated into the air, her eyes rolling back in her head - as is the body of her sister. After a familiar whir of magical energy, they simply...disappear.
If Amaalik survives, he will accompany the adventurers to the next floor. Read or paraphrase the following:

Karthax's magical runes hum about you, lifting you from the blood-stained floor upon which you stand. Your thoughts wander to the sisters - and how many times they must have fought the same battles. At what point, you wonder, will the bloodshed stop? Why would a god allow such to continue for so long?
Your thoughts swirling as rapidly as the magical runes now encircling your body, your final thought as darkness creeps over your vision is: how could a god who allows such ever be considered good?
If either Faradel or Kyreen are the last sister left, and they in turn defeated by the adventurers, read the following:
You might have suspected as much - the clues were there, that you were just a pawn and nothing more, caught in a pursuit of hatred.

Karthax's magical runes hum about you, lifting you from the blood-stained floor upon which you stand. Your thoughts wander to the sisters - and how many times they must have fought these same battles. At what point, you wonder, will the bloodshed stop? Why would a god allow such to continue for so long?
Your thoughts swirling as rapidly as the magical runes now encircling your body, your final thought as darkness creeps over your vision is: how could a god who allows such ever be considered good?

entries.name: Background
entries: Jarl Hjálmŷr hails from a frost giant clan isolated deep within a northern mountain range, far from what most would consider civilization. Descended from a line of powerful shamans, Hjálmŷr quickly rose through the tribal ranks, and despite standing only 18-feet-tall (small for a frost giant), quickly becoming a warrior renowned not only for his ferocity and prowess in battle, but also for his cunning and intelligence. More than a worthy opponent to other rivals within his clan, Hjálmŷr quickly earned the respect of older and more seasoned warriors.

Never satisfied with achieving renown as a warrior, in his arrogance Hjálmŷr set his mind on a more enticing prize — being recognized as Jarl of his tribe. After amassing a significant following, Hjálmŷr set about challenging the incumbent Jarl for their seat at the warrior's throne — a hallowed throne constructed of dragon bones and the weapons of conquered enemies. Despite his cunning, Hjálmŷr was blinded by arrogance and lust for the coveted throne — and was thus betrayed by his followers. After a fierce battle, Hjálmŷr’s followers were slain.

Bloodied, battered, and broken, the current Jarl decreed that rather than honor Hjálmŷr with a warrior’s death, instead he would be shunned by all the northern frost giant clans and cast out from his home range. Should Hjálmŷr even step foot in their lands again, he would be forever denied his place at the All-Father’s table with his ancestors.

Denied what he viewed as his rightful place as Jarl, Hjálmŷr descended from his mountain range with a seething desire to seek power and overthrow those who cast him out. Soon Hjálmŷr would have vengeance.

Communicating with ancestral spirits that had also been denied their place at the All-Father’s table, Hjálmŷr began to unlock forbidden and nearly forgotten magical secrets. However, Hjálmŷr was not content with merely being able to summon the spirits of long slain warriors and binding others to his will. Once he tasted of the chalice of power, he relentlessly thirsted for more, and was lured by Karthax. Seeking to achieve unimaginable power, Karthax ensnared Hjálmŷr, offering precisely what Hjálmŷr desired — unimaginable magical powers and  a Jarl’s seat within The Living Tower. In exchange, Hjálmŷr would remain Karthax’s...guest...until such time he would be released once more upon the world to seek his vengeance.
To this day, Hjálmŷr sits upon a throne of death within the tower, a self-proclaimed Jarl who rules over the spirits of the dead and longs for the day when he might unleash his new-found might.

In his servitude, Jarl Hjálmŷr has lost all sense of time, but believes at least several centuries have passed and that the time of his release is nigh. This floor is kept frigidly cold by a magical artifact within the Jarl's treasure room, which also contains a number of potential magical artifacts that may be of use to an adventuring party.

entries.name: Author's Vision
entries: This floor was created with a Norse theme for one of the author's close friends who is endlessly intrigued by Norse mythology. We wanted to instill a significant amount of roleplaying in this floor, focusing on Hjálmŷr's ego that allows an endless number of ways to challenge characters. We envisioned several possibilities on how this floor could proceed:

items: The adventurers partake in a feast, with Hjálmŷr choosing to challenge Rorak in the fighting pit, thereby demonstrating his prowess to his guests.
If the characters choose to insult Hjálmŷr, he may challenge and defeat one of them instead.
Following an initial bout in the fighting pit, an ensuing feast could add an element of gruesomeness due to the cannibalistic nature of the frost giant.
Should the adventurers be more cautious, Borr and Rán could cause endless mischief with their magical abilities.
Should characters need a nudge, Edmond's {@i faerie fire} spell could be a catalyst for an assault on the Jarl as it could frighten the frost giant and incapacitate the Draugr.
The {@b Orb of Bitterness} within the Jarl's treasure room is a powerful artifact, but extremely dangerous — it could be modified if needed.
The winter wolf, Varsúlfr, plays a very minor role — she could become a dire wolf instead, or removed altogether to make the floor slightly easier for less experienced characters.

entries: There are numerous opportunities for roleplaying:

items: Have fun roleplaying Jarl Hjálmŷr - make him as boisterous and egotistical as possible.
Edmond the Red is in fact cowardly at heart and may betray the adventurers to Hjálmŷr.
Should either Edmond or Rorak survive, consider having them accompany the party to the next floor — or consider them expendable.

entries: Consider weaving the following lore into the roleplaying:

items: Hjálmŷr suggests Karthax was once one of the "old gods" - and that he had heard the name associated with a devious trickster.
Karthax may have been responsible for the construction of The Living Tower — perhaps due to some great cataclysm or conflict between the gods.

While he has no idea what is on other floors, Hjálmŷr knows the tower must have been around for some time before he discovered it. He has no idea how many floors it has nor how many creatures are held captive.
Hjálmŷr knows the time will come when he will be set free once more — but he no longer has any concept of how long he has been within.

Karthax rarely communicates directly with Hjálmŷr, choosing instead to leave the giant to his own devices. On occasion though Hjálmŷr can sense Karthax' presence, as though the being is...checking in.

entries.name: Hjálmŷr, Jarl of the Frost Giants
entries: A frost giant of unknown age, Jarl Hjálmŷr has been trapped within The Living Tower for countless ages. Rendered immortal by Karthax, Hjálmŷr has lost all concept of time, and will often ramble of his deeds to any who listen (willingly or not) — his retinue of Draugr, his winter wolf, Varsúlfr (the only creature Hjálmŷr might actually care about), the two ice mephits, Borr and Rán (servants of Karthax who occasionally visit Hjálmŷr’s floor on behalf of Karthax), and any beings who happen to be teleported to the floor for Karthax’s testing or entertainment.

Standing 18-feet tall, Hjálmŷr wears a great helm capped with the horns crafted of dragon spine bones tipped with claws from the same, and wears battle scarred mail. His eyes glow with an unearthly hue behind irises the color of glacial ice, and glint with malice and cunning. A long white beard, carefully braided, frames his pale blue skin. Hjálmŷr bears a massive greataxe that is never far from his reach, its blade pitted from hundreds of battles.

Hjálmŷr is arrogant and boastful, convinced in his own superiority. For the first few centuries he was entrapped within The Living Tower, Hjálmŷr would immediately challenge newcomers to battle, slaying them indiscriminately.

Hjálmŷr soon grew bored of such slaughter, and will now entertain guests, regaling them with sagas of his own crafting that boast of his great deeds and accomplishments — some true, others more far-fetched and outlandish. Such sagas often take hours, with Hjálmŷr insisting his favorite verses be repeated endlessly by the Draugr, and all the while both mead and meat are served until all fall asleep or pass out at their tables.

As with all his playthings, Hjálmŷr eventually tires of such games, and challenges his “guests” to combat in his fighting pit. Inevitably Hjálmŷr is victorious, often playing with his exhausted and weaker opponents while boasting of his strength before delivering the final blow. In a gruesome twist, the dead are butchered and spit-roasted, to be served to Hjálmŷr’s remaining guests, Varsúlfr, and the Draugr.

Hjálmŷr fears only one thing — fire. He noticeably avoids the fire in his hall, and any sudden appearance of flames from any source requires Hjálmŷr to make a {@b {@dc 18} Wisdom} saving throw with disadvantage, becoming frightened of the flames on a  failed save and loosening his control of the Draugr. Should Hjálmŷr fail his saving throw, the Draugr become incapacitated for 1 turn until they can regain their composure from their master's response to fire.

{@b Roleplaying Hjálmŷr.} Hjálmŷr does not take well to insults and insists on being addressed by his self-proclaimed honorific of Jarl. He takes great joy in being worshiped by the Draugr, who obey his every command and do not tolerate disrespect to their lord.

Hjálmŷr insists on his guests having what he perceives as a “good time”, despite many of them preemptively cowering in obvious terror of the Jarl’s next outburst. Hjálmŷr can be portrayed with the following behaviors/phrases:

items: - To the adventurers: {@i “Now you must dine with me — bear witness to the hospitality of Hjálmŷr!” or “Guests! Let us drink to the All-Father!”}
- To the Draugr: {@i “By damn you miserable worms, can you not see the tankards of our guests run dry and their plates are without?!?! Bring mead and meat!”}
- To Edmond the Red: “Skald! Our guests grow weary — the saga of Hjálmŷr must be sung once more!”
- If challenged or disrespected: {@i “By the All-Father, you WILL show respect to your Jarl while you dine in HIS hall and under HIS protection!”}
- While reminiscing about past glories: *“Ah! Let me tell you of how I conquered Grumor the Orm — now THAT was a fight worth a long tale!"

entries.name: Varsúlfr
entries: A massive, snow-white female winter wolf, Varsúlfr accompanied Hjálmŷr when he was exiled after his attempted overthrow of the Jarl. Varsúlfr is seldom found far from her master, and will aggressively posture and snarl at any who irritate or challenge Hjálmŷr. During the telling of a saga or while entertaining in the hall, Varsúlfr will seemingly doze contentedly at the base of Hjálmŷr’s throne, though her ears will be constantly alert (noticed with a successful DC 15 Wisdom (Animal Handling or Nature) check. When Hjálmŷr is in the fighting pit, Varsúlfr will eagerly prowl the perimeter, slavering at the thought of a fresh, raw meal.

entries.name: Draugr
entries: The seven Draugr that make up Jarl Hjálmŷr’s entourage are the reanimated corpses of slain warriors that contain the souls of Hjálmŷr’s ancestors and followers that have been brought back by Hjálmŷr. They are clad in tattered hides and bear greataxes, spears, and crude jewelry symbolizing frost giant runes and idols. They are unwaveringly loyal to Hjálmŷr, and speak in rasping voices that remind one of ice blowing across a desolate frozen wasteland. They are: Arne, Birger, Egil, Gorm, Knud, Trove, and Ulf — though they can't remember their true names nor origins, only that they serve at Hjálmŷr’s will.

The Draugr will attack only if directed by Hjálmŷr or to defend themselves. They will not slay a character outright, but will subdue (reduce to 0 hit points, or grapple/restrain) them. The magic of Karthax keeps their souls bound to Hjálmŷr’s floor, and even if their bodies are shattered their spirits remain contained within — until a newly reanimated corpse can be used to contain that soul.
{@b Roleplaying the Draugr.} The Draugr speak little, but when engaged will voice phrases such as the following:

items: When someone is asking about their history: "{@i I know not...only that we are here to serve.}"
When guarding an area: {@i “The Jarl has decreed this space as his own — you are not to pass.”} or {@i “The Jarl would not wish it.”}
When challenged aggressively or entering combat: "For glory and Hjálmŷr! For the All-Father!"

entries.name: Ice Mephits: Borr and Rán
entries: Karthax occasionally sends two ice mephits, Borr and Rán, to keep an eye on Hjálmŷr. They have the ability to teleport anywhere on this floor, as well as communicate telepathically with any being therein. They are tolerated by Hjálmŷr, as they will also feed his ego, urging him to retell his tales over and over while they partake in his grand feasts. They will on occasion play pranks on Hjálmŷr, the Draugr, or visitors for both their own entertainment and that of Karthax. They do not dare challenge Varsúlfr and give her a wide berth, as her swiftness and savagery strike fear into the mephits.

The magic of Karthax prevents Borr and Rán from being slain. Should they die, their bodies will reform within 2d8 turns, though they will be understandably upset with the inconvenience of their exploding bodies.
{@b Roleplaying Borr and Rán.} Borr and Rán are minor characters, who cause all sorts of mischief on behalf of Karthax. They may, for example, do the following:

items: Telepathically communicate with one of the characters during a saga: {@i “Oh, not this old tale again... You should ask him about the one-eyed Jarl!”} This will set Hjálmŷr on a tirade and cause him to challenge the characters as he thinks they are in league with Torsten One-Eye, the Jarl Hjálmŷr challenged for supremacy.
Encase the legs of a Draugr in a block of ice with their Frost Breath ability, causing the Draugr to fall and reducing its movement speed to 0.
They may hide Hjálmŷr’s personal items, such as his mead horn or helmet, causing Hjálmŷr to go on a tirade about {@i “those damned servants of Karthax!”}

Seeing characters grow weary, they may appear and state {@i “Great Jarl! Your guests eagerly await the retelling of verse four hundred eighty-three of the saga of Hjálmŷr! One more time!” before chortling and teleporting away in glee.}"

entries.name: Rorak
entries: Known as Rorak the Bold, he is one of the last two remaining guests of a recent visiting group. Rorak is a tall, muscular warrior clad in plate armor. Having seen all his boon companions but Edmond the Red slain in the fighting pit, Rorak awaits his fate with resignation, determined to at least give a fight for the ages. Seeing the characters arrive gives a burst of hope to Rorak, but alas his fate is sealed shortly after the character’s arrival. Rorak attempted to save his companions in the fighting pit but was restrained by the Draugr, who now watch over Rorak closely.
{@b Roleplaying Rorak.} Rorak is a steadfast and grim warrior who has all but given up hope. When engaged over the welcome feast, he speaks in hushed tones:

items: When questioned how his party arrived within the tower: {@i “We were lured by the promise of power, glory, and treasure — we had seen several floors prior, but here we have met our end”.}
Rorak’s spirit is broken, having been restrained numerous times by several Draugr and beaten into submission by the same.
Rorak is vigilantly guarded by two Draugr who forcibly make him consume meat and mead, and join in (halfheartedly) with verses of the sagas sung by Edmond.

The arrival of new visitors hastens Hjálmŷr’s plans with Rorak: Hjálmŷr will “celebrate” the arrival of new “guests” with a demonstration of his strength in the fighting pit, as he has grown tired of Rorak’s lack of enthusiasm toward his hospitality.

entries.name: Edmond
entries: A wandering minstrel going by the name Edmond the Red, he seeks renown as a bard; playing in taverns and at fairs throughout a relatively short career. Edmond happened upon Rorak’s group, and decided to pursue the opportunity to witness great and heroic deeds. So named for his mane of shocking red hair as well as the crimson cloak he wears, Edmond has found favor with Hjálmŷr, as his quick memory enabled him to learn several of the rather lengthy sagas sung in Hjálmŷr ‘s hall. A quick wit, Edmond quickly invented a number of new and overly flattering verses, which he uses to keep in Hjálmŷr’s favor, knowing that the giant quickly tires of his guests. Thus he will often stand beside Jarl Hjálmŷr’s throne, strumming lute until his fingers are bloodied and his voice is hoarse after countless hours.

Hjálmŷr views Edmond as his personal skald, but in reality Edmond is terrified of the giant — only his talents, quick wit, and willingness to do anything to desperately stay in the giant’s favor keeps the rather cowardly bard alive. Still, given the chance he will share what little knowledge he has gleaned about this floor with the adventurers, but if caught by Hjálmŷr or the Draugr, will quickly blame the characters for any transgressions.

{@b Roleplaying Edmond.} Being viewed as Hjálmŷr’s skald has its advantages - Edmond has been allowed to view Hjálmŷr’s treasure room, containing a horde seized from visitors to his floor, and the giant, arrogantly viewing Edmond as a trusted confidant and loyal servant, revealed his dislike, even fear, of fire. Edmond voices the following:

items: There is a great glowing orb containing some sort of arcane power in a treasure room behind the Jarl’s throne, along with countless weapons and a horde of gold and gems. Hjálmŷr quickly becomes bored, and is prone to violent outbursts if challenged.
If questioned on his role, Edmond hisses {@i “We all do what we must to stay alive — I have no wish to be a giant’s supper. Hardly a fitting end for one so talented and famous as I!”}

If asked about potential weaknesses or vulnerabilities, Edmond states {@i “See how he avoids his own fire? He uses it only for entertaining guests, lest they freeze to death ‘ere he can finish them off. My poor fingertips are nigh frostbitten off!”}

If questioned how he came to this floor, Edmond sniffs and states {@i “‘twas my own damned fault — I left the comforts of playing in warm taverns to seek new inspiration with Rorak and his band of fools. What a fool I was — I’d give anything for a warm bed and hearth.”}

entries: Edmond will aid the characters however he can, provided he sees hope in escaping. This aid may be covert, and he will only openly help if there is clear hope of escape. But, being the coward he is, should a plan go awry he will be the first to blame any problems on the newcomers: {@i “See my Jarl?!? See what they have brought to your halls? They have dishonored your hospitality!”}

entries.name: 1. Teleportation Glyph

entries: A nimbus of power surrounds you, and the hairs on the nape of your neck rise with static electricity. Glowing arcane runes swirl about, rising above your head as the hum and crackle of energy overwhelms your ears. Your hand passes through one of the runes as you reach out in curiosity as black shadows descend upon you. Silence and darkness greet you as you feel consciousness rapidly slip away.

The first thing you notice as you ascend out of the darkness is a bitter cold as you draw in breath. Immediately the tips of your fingers begin to grow numb, and as you open your eyes, your exhalation condenses in a thick cloud of fog. You can already feel ice crystals forming on your lashes as you take in your surroundings. Light dances eerily through the ice, flickering about as though by torches or the like. The arcane symbols that have surrounded you descend, the incessant hum slowly fading into obscurity.

This room is 20-feet wide and 40-feet long. Hoarfrost and rime coat solid granite walls that reflect light oddly, casting a somewhat bluish hue around the room. Once the characters have teleported into this floor, the runes fall silent, and the symbols on the floor grow dark. Growing from the ceiling 25 feet above, heavy icicles dangle precariously, as though a sudden sharp noise could cause one to drop and potentially impale an adventurer below.

After a few minutes, a steady drum of footsteps echo weirdly off the ice-covered walls. A pair of {@b Draugr} walk into the entrance, bearing sheathed blades and harnessed axes. They pause a respectful distance away, cold blue eyes gazing forth from ancient frozen faces beneath horned helms. The Draugr greet the adventurers, and invite them to meet with Hjálmŷr:

{@i “Welcome, honored guests of Karthax, to the hall of Jarl Hjálmŷr. Our great and worthy lord would welcome you in a way befitting your noble bearing, as he does all guests who come to seek his allegiance and favor. Prepare yourselves appropriately for an audience with your lord.}"

If attacked, the Draugr will summon reinforcements to subdue the adventurers, or wait until the bitter cold takes its toll — periodically have the adventurers make a {@b {@dc 10} Constitution} saving throw or suffer a level of exhaustion.

Should a loud noise occur, such as shouting or combat, each turn roll a d10. On a roll of 1, an icicle falls at a random location in the room. If a character is beneath, they must make a {@b {@dc 13} Dexterity} saving throw, taking 22 (4d10) piercing damage on a failed save. If they fail their save by 5 or more, they are also knocked unconscious.

entries.name: 2. Draugr's Guard Room

entries: The humanoids guide you to a large, sturdy oak door. In a small room, an overly large round table is littered with playing cards and knucklebones. Countless pierce marks, made by daggers while the humanoids played at daggers pockmark the table. Along one side of the wall lies a weapon rack containing humanoid-sized maces, axes, spears, and a longsword neatly stowed away.

The Draugr give the adventurers sufficient time to make themselves presentable and take in their surroundings. They will wait patiently until the adventurers are ready, or until they can no longer bear the cold. A number of ancient copper, silver, and gold coins are also littered about the table; a successful {@b {@dc 16} Intelligence (History)} check will indicate they are at least several hundred years old, and were once used by northern barbarian clans.
The Draugr indicate that the adventurers are allowed possession of their weapons and will allow them to be peace-bonded, but dire consequences await any who draw steel within the Jarl's hall.

entries.name: 3. Hall of Jarl Hjálmŷr

entries: The flicker of dancing lights, perhaps the promise of a warm fire, can be seen down the hall. The humanoids accompanying you move to either side as you enter, announcing: {@i “Hjálmŷr, Mighty lord, conqueror of Grumor the Orm, champion of the Gelu mountain range and rightful Jarl of the Frostlake clan bids you welcome to his hall! All visitors of Karthax are welcome to partake in food, drink, flame, and song. Glory to Jarl Hjálmŷr!” }

Four massive, long tables are set as though for a great feast. Meat, sausages, wheels of cheese, tankards of mead and ale, and loaves of thick bread litter each table. At one, a grim-faced, armor-clad warrior is flanked by two of the hulking humanoids. The warrior nods in your direction, and you detect perhaps a glimmer of hope behind his eyes. The two beings who initially greeted you follow behind, and another three are seated, partaking of the feast. The roaring fire in the middle of the hall does little to drive away the bitter cold, though any such warmth is more than welcome.

Tapestries, tattered of age and stiff with the cold, line the walls and depict great battles — that of a giant battling a great white dragon, of the same giant beheading another, and other battle similar scenes. Before you upon a great carved granite throne atop a grand dais, stands a gigantic figure clad in mail and a horned helmet. His eyes glow with an unearthly hue behind irises the color of glacial ice, and glint with malice and cunning. A white, braided beard frames his pockmarked and scarred face. Atop his dais, the giant’s head nearly reaches the ceiling above.

To one side of the dais, a shivering figure clad in a red cloak holds a lute, and studies you with muted hope. A great white wolf slowly rises, stretches, and yawns before a low, deep rumble comes from deep within its chest.
As the adventurers enter, read or paraphrase the following:

A great, snow-white wolf slowly rises from a dais across the great hall. The hand of a massive giant gently reaches down and strokes the wolf between its ears: {@i “Peace, Varsúlfr. These are honored guests within these halls!”} Addressing you directly, the giant booms: {@i “Tell me now - what great saga has brought you to my hall?”}

Hjálmŷr will question the characters until he is satisfied with their answers — what brought them to The Living Tower, what floors they have visited, any news of the outside world, and similar. He will, in turn, reveal the following:

items: Hjálmŷr has been a guest of Karthax for many years — after a century, Hjálmŷr stopped counting. Eventually, the bargain will be fulfilled.

On a successful {@b {@dc 17} Charisma (Persuasion)} check, Hjálmŷr will indicate the bartered knowledge for servitude — though he admits he does not know what Karthax considers servitude other than sitting in his hall.

entries: Otherwise Hjálmŷr will reveal little else of importance, and deflect questions back to the characters. Should they become insistent, Hjálmŷr will grab his massive, pitted greataxe and shout:
{@i “Enough! It is I who asks questions in my hall. You shall have answers when I decide!”}
Eventually, Hjálmŷr will grow weary and impatient with questioning his guests, and will insist on a feast and the telling of his saga:

{@i “Bah. The hour grows late, and I can tell you are famished. Feast and drink with me! Skald! The saga of Jarl Hjálmŷr must be sung on this auspicious day! Let us welcome our new guests as per the traditions of the All-Father decree!”}

Allow the characters to further question Hjálmŷr, though only in a respectful manner — any perceived slights against the giant result in the Draugr drawing arms and an immediate cease to the “merriment” until the characters are appropriately subdued, even disarmed (actual combat not required at the GM’s discretion). If necessary, have Varsúlfr enter battle as well — only have Hjálmŷr settle things down if needed. Otherwise, at any combat have him bang on his throne and roar in laughter:
{@i “Not a true feast until blood is shed! Come, show us what you are made of!” }

At any point, have Borr and Rán teleport into the room to observe the merriment, and on occasion pull pranks as per the {@i Dramatis Personae}. When asked, have Hjálmŷr dismiss them as {@i “mere irritating fleas, servants of Karthax. Pay no attention to those vermin.”}
Eventually, Hjálmŷr may decide to prove his superiority over his new visitors, and choose either a strong adventurer from amidst the new arrivals or {@b Rorak} to challenge him in the fighting pit.

entries.name: 4. Fighter's Armory

entries: Several racks of weapons and armor are found in small rooms on either side of a 60-foot-long hallway. Carefully stowed and meticulously maintained, any number of axes, spears, swords, warhammers, mauls, and maces are held within these rooms. The occasional helm, shield, or suit of mail are also found within.

A successful {@b {@dc 13} Intelligence (History)} check by a character examining the items found in the armory will indicate that they are found from a wide variety of sources and at various points throughout the last few centuries.

At the GM's discretion, the characters may identify a weapon of the GM's choice that is somewhat more ornate and has a faintly magical hue, noticed with a successful {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (Arcana)} check. The weapon could be a +1 or +2 magical weapon.

entries.name: 5. Fighting Pit

entries: From the hallway you emerge into a large room perhaps  150-feet long and 70-feet wide. A long, oval pit looms before you, 15-feet deep. Sharpened wooden stakes coated with icicles (some stained red) line the perimeter of the pit, and within lies the promise of a gruesome fate - that of broken weapons and dismembered body parts cast about the pit.

In each corner of the room, crudely constructed spectator stands have been erected. Tattered rags, many stained with blood, have been strung in a gruesome display along the walls - various symbols and heraldry upon them, some of which you recognize as great houses or noble families, others of which elude you. Your undead guards indicate for you to be seated in the stands.

A successful {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (History)} check reveals that the heraldry on several of the tattered cloth is perhaps up to several hundred years old, indicating how long Hjálmŷr has been imprisoned within The Living Tower by Karthax.

The Fighting Pit is where Hjálmŷr challenges his guests and offers sacrifice to the All-Father, while the Draugr carefully watches over the spectators. Before a challenge, Hjálmŷr will retire to his private bedchamber and preparation room to arm himself and prepare for battle, while the Draugr allow the challenger to prepare in the Fighter's Armory. Once all spectators are seated, read or paraphrase the following, assuming Hjálmŷr has chosen Rorak the Bold as his challenger (replace as necessary with any other character):

A silence descends in the icy room. Slowly, menacingly, the undead begin to raise their voices as one in a low, solemn chant in an ancient language. Their voices slowly rise, their chants causing your blood to run colder than you thought possible, until from the hall from which you came emerges Rorak, forced by one of the undead beings. The grim-faced warrior, bearing a greatsword and a mixed look of determination and fear behind his eyes, acknowledges you with a slight nod and gesture of farewell before he is shoved into the pit.
