Before entering the pit himself, read the following said by the Jarl:

{@i “All-Father, we offer sacrifice to your glory and that of the Ancestors. All within are honored by your spirit and presence. Only one shall emerge this night to feast, the other shall dine in your hall this night. We offer you a sacrifice of strength and blood with this contest!”}

The pit is lined with sharpened stakes of fire-hardened wood. Any creature forced against the walls of the pit must succeed on a {@b {@dc 13} Dexterity} saving throw, taking 4 (1d8) piercing damage on a failed save. If the saving throw is failed by 5 or more, the target takes 9 (2d8) piercing damage and they are considered restrained, as they are impaled or otherwise caught on a stake.
Should Hjálmŷr fight Rorak without any party members stepping in, read or paraphrase the following:

The battle between the giant and the man is short-lived and one-sided, and though Rorak gives a reasonable accounting of himself, he tires quickly in the frigid pit. Hjálmŷr contents himself to toy with the warrior for a time, even taking a slash across the arm, before landing a brutal blow, decapitating Rorak with an almost lazy sweep of his axe. Holding the warrior’s head above him, he announces: {@i “Thy will be done! We honor this brave warrior as those before him. We shall continue in your name!”}

Hjálmŷr tosses Rorak’s head out of the pit and toward the kitchen before stripping the body of armor, dismembering it, and tossing arms, legs, and torso out of the pit. One leg is tossed to Varsúlfr, who eagerly tears into it.

entries.name: 6. Draugr's Kitchen

entries: The smell of roasting meat causes your mouth to water, and the kitchen before you is heated by a pair of spits over shimmering coals. Several gigantic kegs are neatly stacked against the wall, one of which has been tapped and slowly drips mead against the stone floor. Other goods - sacks of flour, spices, and other goods are also organized and methodically stored. A butcher's table with utensils sits between the two spits. This would be an otherwise welcome sight, until you notice the partially dismembered remains of a humanoid over one of the fires...

The Draugr use this kitchen to prepare meals for Hjálmŷr's guests. Karthax ensures there is no shortage of food, magically filling kegs of mead and providing other goods to this floor, including the occasional boar or other game should no visitors reach this floor. A successful {@b {@dc 13} Intelligence (Investigation)} or {@b Wisdom (Perception)} check indicates the roasting humanoid has been roasting for over a day, no doubt a companion of Rorak's adventuring party.
A Draugr Kitchen? Surely they jest, as I've smelt the "food" made within... although those fat mephits seem to enjoy their meals.  〄

entries.name: 7. Holding Chamber

entries: A heavy set of plain, but sturdy, oak doors are barred from the kitchen side. A set of iron bars is set on one side at eye level. Peering within, you can see dirty and unkept beds on either side of what appears to be a small, seldom used bedchamber. There is no movement within.

The door to this room is barred with a heavy oak beam, requiring a successful {@b {@dc 13} Strength (Athletics)} check to remove (made with advantage if two or more creatures are attempting to remove it).

Six beds are on either side of this room, covered in tattered blankets stiff with ice and frost. The room is clearly seldom used, perhaps as a sort of holding cell for unruly guests. Should a character search one of the beds, a frozen corpse, thin from apparent starvation, is curled up beneath several layers of rags.
One chest at the base of one of the beds contains crudely carved wooden utensils, a cup, and a wooden plate.

entries.name: 8. Hjálmŷr's Armory

entries: Behind a heavy set of drapes that lead to the fighting pit, a wide hallway lined with tattered shields on either side leads to a giant-sized armory. A series of oak target dummies, clearly heavily used, line one side of the room. Two tables line a second wall, where a series of axes and shields lie scattered about as though Hjálmŷr had rummaged through, looking for a favorite. Their edges are keen and lovingly maintained, as evidenced by a number of well used whetstones scattered among them. In one corner of the room, a great helm is set atop a rack also holding a giant-sized suit of heavy plate armor, vambraces, greaves, and sabatons. Despite the cold, each and every item is well oiled and free of rust and ice.
Additional weapons, including greatswords, warhammers, mauls, and others are proudly mounted on the walls amidst shields depicting various heraldry - no doubt trophies taken from defeated guests.

This room holds seven axes — the {@item Greataxe of Fury|gp_karthax} and three other greataxes, two battle axes that Hjálmŷr uses simultaneously (one in each hand), and one smaller handaxe that is often found tucked into Hjálmŷr's belt. He seldom uses a shield or the giant-sized plate armor, preferring instead his mail. The giant-sized plate armor weighs a total of 170 lbs should a creature attempt to carry it.

entries.name: 9. Jarl's Quarters
entries: Hjálmŷr's personal bedroom, used only for sleeping. The door to the Hall of Jarl Hjálmŷr (Area 3) is locked, opened with a successful {@b {@dc 17} Dexterity (Thieves' Tools)} check. There is a secret door leading to the Jarl's Treasure Room (Area 10), discovered with a successful {@b {@dc 18} Intelligence (Investigation)} check.

entries.name: 10. Jarl's Treasure Room

entries: A sudden blast of air so cold it is nearly unbearable assaults your skin as you open the door to this room. Unlike others in this floor, there is an unnerving stillness to the air in the room. An eerie, pale blue light softly emanates from within. The cold is even more bitter than elsewhere on this floor.

The treasure room can also be accessed via a locked door behind a tapestry in the Hall of Jarl Hjálmŷr behind the giant's throne. This door can be unlocked with a successful {@b {@dc 19} Dexterity (Sleight of Hand)} check using thieves' tools, or forced open with a {@b {@dc 20} Strength (Athletics)} check. The door is not trapped, and opened with a separate key carried by Hjálmŷr at all times.

The Jarl's treasure room is littered with plunder taken from centuries' worth of visitors to this floor. It also contains an {@b Orb of Bitterness} that drains the heat from all nearby sources and keeps this floor at a frigid temperature. At the end of each turn spent in this room, a creature must make progressively more difficult Constitution saving throws, starting at DC 14 (then 15, 16 etc) or suffer from one level of exhaustion. If a creature has resistance or immunity to cold damage, they make their saving throw with advantage.
As the characters enter the room, read or paraphrase the following:

As you enter the room, the pale blue light pulses noticeably. Each step further you take causes your chest to constrict with cold and soon you are shivering uncontrollable. Wonders lie before you - chests, some open, overflowing with treasure, sacks of coins, bolts of silk cloth, tapestries, and countless weapons lie scattered in a corner, almost carelessly discarded. A large gold statue of a lion watches over the room, its eyes seeming to follow you.
Amidst it all, a pale blue orb is precariously placed on a carved marble pedestal in the center of the room. The air is still and silent.

The room contains four sturdy chests, two open and two locked. The locked chests require {@b {@dc 14} Dexterity (Sleight of Hand)} checks to open, and are trapped with a frost glaze. In the bitter cold, this is difficult to notice, requiring a {@b {@dc 19} Intelligence (Arcana)} check that indicates a crystalline lattice attached to the clasp of the chest. If triggered, each creature in a 20-foot-radius sphere takes 2 (1d4) cold damage and the area is covered in the frost glaze, considered difficult terrain. Objects coated in the glaze require a successful {@b {@dc 13} Dexterity} check to use without dropping, and any fragile items will shatter if dropped. The trap may be disarmed with a {@i dispel magic} spell or {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (Arcana)} check.

The two open chests contain treasure equal to 500 gp each. Each of the locked chests contain gems in addition to gold, equal in value to 1500 gp each. A solid gold statue of a lion weighing 300 lbs stands in a corner of the room as though keeping watch over the treasure.

The sacks of coins contain lesser treasure - copper and silver pieces worth 500 gp in total. A character that spends at least two turns and makes a successful {@b {@dc 15} Wisdom (Perception)} check will also discover a small, finely crafted silver candle holder, its handle carved into the likeness of a dragon — a {@b Candle of Scrying.}

The weapons in the corner of the room appear to be of lesser quality than the ones in either the fighter's armory or Hjálmŷr's armory. However, if a character spends at least two turns and makes a successful {@b {@dc 14} Intelligence (Arcana)} check, they will notice a large, plain heavy shield that glows faintly ({@b shield, +1}). If they succeed on their Arcana check by 3 or more, they instead discover a magical greatsword; a {@item Frostbrand Greatsword}.

entries.name: Completing this Floor
entries: Jarl Hjálmŷr's floor may be completed if Hjálmŷr is defeated. Karthax insists on keeping Hjálmŷr alive for their own entertainment, and will magically prevent a killing blow. Read or paraphrase the following:

As you prepare to deliver the final strike to your host, a strong silence blankets the room. As your blade descends, its momentum slows until the keen edge is but an inch from the incapacitated giant's exposed flesh.

A flood of emotions overwhelm your senses: hesitation, frustration, and pity. It takes a moment before you realize that these emotions are being projected into your psyche by another. It seems that Hjálmŷr is under Karthax' watchful eye, and whatever the reason might be, the giant will be kept alive.
A faint familiar tingling pulses over your body, and you know your time left on this frigid floor is ending.
If suitable, give the characters a few moments to explore any remaining areas of this floor before reading or paraphrasing the following:

The now familiar sensation of Karthax's magic washes over you as your head begins to spin. You purge your stomach as the nausea intensifies, before losing consciousness. As the darkness descends, your last sensation is a bellow of frustration and anger, no doubt from your former host.

entries.name: Background
entries: Before the Great Cataclysm, the region in which The Living Tower stands was once a hot, humid jungle near a dormant volcano. Countless species of plants and animals thrived in this environment, and the tribes of mortal species that lived within had an abundance of food. Deep lakes and rivers crisscrossed the land filled with fish, eels, and waterfowl; the great, ancient trees supported countless species of animals both beneath on the shadowy jungle floor and within a canopy that produced a diversity of fruit and other foods undreamed of. Medicinal plants were common, and the denizens of this jungle were prosperous.

Despite the relative peace of this jungle, there were nonetheless dangerous threats throughout. Large caimans lurked amidst calmer waterways, great cats stalked game from the dense foliage, and even the inhabitants of the jungle would on occasion wage war amongst themselves. The greatest of these predators were the fiercely territorial hydras — ravenous multi-headed reptilian creatures that dwelled within some of the more boggy wetlands within the region.

The tribes that dwelled within this region were for the most part isolated from greater society, and despite numerous pilgrimages from the so-called civilized outer world to enlighten these reclusive bands in the ways of the Eld Gods, seldom could they find them. Frequently such visitors were afflicted with virulent jungle fevers, lost within the tangle and driven mad before eventually finding their way out once again, or simply never heard from again.

Despite limited contact with the outside world and even less knowledge of events therein, the Great Cataclysm would decimate this ecosystem. In their fury, the Eld Gods raised a great fire mountain from within the depths of the jungle, one that would spew forth countless tons of ash and poisonous sulfurous gas into the atmosphere. The violent magics that raised this volcano laid waste to the jungle, annihilating almost all of the region and those within in but a few short days. Creatures that could flee did so, but most perished — engulfed in a pyroclastic flow that consumed their bodies or showered them with molten rock. Only a few pitiful remnants of this once glorious tribute to life would survive its transformation into a barren wasteland of ash and dust.

At the edge of the jungle, a hydra nest nestled against a peaceful riverbank that contained a single egg was miraculously spared from the pyroclastic flow and volcanic bombs that rained down upon the region. Hatching amidst the chaos and destruction, and just as the choking volcanic gasses were dissipating, the young hydra found an abundance of food. Not needing to hunt nor compete with other predators, the hydra — the last of its kind — rapidly grew to an enormous size.

When Karthax constructed The Living Tower, the hydra, known as Khuzza, was beginning to run out of easy prey. Seeing the great creature and knowing that the species would soon become extinct without divine intervention, Karthax brought Khuzza within. Countless visitors to the tower have since satiated the great reptile.

entries.name: Author's Vision
entries: Characters will initially fall to their apparent doom, only to be saved by the magic of Veraetis, supposed leader of a cult devoted to Khuzza. Each individual will be imprisoned in one of the various rooms at random, several of which are linked to the NPCs Tiarsus Tralee and Artuk the Half-Orc. This floor is in essence a jailbreak — characters must fight their way free and defeat both the cult of Khuzza and the hydra itself.

Khuzza has become habituated to either feasting on decaying remains or being willingly offered a meal by the cultists that inhabit this floor. The hydra cares little of whom it consumes, cultist or prisoner — the only exception being Jouslir, whom the hydra regards with something akin to respect as they are the only humanoid who shows both true devotion and a lack of fear toward the beast.

Veraetis can be portrayed as insane or cold and calculating — the influence of Raz'Drexin clearly having affected her thoughts and enticed her with the promise of the power of demonkind in exchange for raising what might in the future become an army of humanoids serving demonkind.
Depending on the skill level of the characters who enter this floor, an unknown NPC may be sacrificed to a gruesome fate while the characters watch, or one of the NPCs may meet this fate.
When characters are engaged on this floor, consider the following:

items: Artuk the Half-Orc may make an unpredictable source of disruption. As a particularly strong barbarian, he may be able to shatter the cell doors, enabling both his and the character's escape.

The cultists are obedient due to the threat of being fed to Khuzza by either Jouslir or Veraetis. Should they sense weakness, consider having one or more of the cultists aid the characters in their escape.

Veraetis is using the cult of Khuzza as a front to raise an army loyal to her, and by extension the demon, Raz'Drexin (found on a previous floor). As a true believer, if this fact were to be revealed to Jouslir, the human might choose to attack his leader should he view himself as being deceived by her — only to in turn take control of the cult.

Khuzza the hydra is completely indiscriminate in choosing their next meal. Should combat be initiated, the hydra will target random creatures according to the ease with which they can be caught and devoured.

entries: Perpetually ravenous, the last hydra will fill its belly until it can no longer move, then regurgitate its last meal to make room for more. Revolting!  〄

entries.name: Veraetis
entries: A human warlock enthralled by power, Veraetis has been exploring The Living Tower for some time, and has knowledge of this floor as well as the floor inhabited by Raz'Drexin, the shadow demon. Veraetis hails from a wealthy family of merchants who, during her childhood, would travel via caravan and visit major cities. Her parents would set up shop and offer a variety of exotic goods, including rarities procured from distant lands. This would often include ancient artifacts either honestly negotiated for with reputable merchants, or at times bartered for with less scrupulous raiders and looters of tombs, ziggurats, and necropoli. Thus Veraetis developed an interest in both ancient history as well as the nature of magical artifacts.

It was on her family's travels that Veraetis first developed a taste for power as a young woman. One night, Veraetis picked a lock to a chest that she knew held her father's most prized artifacts. Within was but a single, black candle. Not knowing any better, she rashly lit the candle and peered into the crimson flame it emitted and promptly fell into a deep coma.

For several weeks, Veraetis was incapacitated, her furious yet inconsolable family keeping vigil beside her. When she awoke, Veraetis spoke with a deeper, almost sinister tone as though possessed by some unseen power.

The candle was a remnant of the time Ere Cataclysmae, and was once used to commune with demons not of this world. Within the flame she was able to communicate with the mad shadow demon, Raz'Drexin, who at last had found a mortal spirit who could perhaps set him free. In her comatose state, Raz'Drexin ensnared Veraetis' soul, and in exchange for the knowledge she sought, offered a taste of demonic power.

For many long years Veraetis sought out Raz'Drexin, eventually coming across The Living Tower. She willingly entered, Karthax reluctantly offering an audience with the demon in exchange for a place within The Living Tower. The audience was granted, and though Veraetis was unable to free the demon, Raz'Drexin bade her to create a loyal following that would be receptive to his presence and plant the seeds of an army of mortals willing to conquer this world in preparation for the arrival of demonkind.

{@b Roleplaying Veraetis.} Veraetis speaks in delicate tones, almost sweet to the untrained ear, but also dripping with sinister tones. She is charismatic and manipulative, whispering suggestions into the ears of potentially receptive mortals, tempting them with promises of power in exchange for unwavering loyalty. To her, Khuzza and this cult is merely a front, a situation that presented itself to mask her true intent: to create a cult devoted to her, and by extension, Raz'Drexin and demonkind.
Veraetis can be portrayed as follows:

items: When tempting an individual with entering service into the Cult of Khuzza:  "{@i Now then, we can either look to provide our host with a full meal to satiate their hunger, or but a morsel to demonstrate your loyalty and win their favor. Which would you prefer?}"
When directing Jouslir, her enforcer:  "{@i Jouslir! This guest of ours appears to need some additional convincing...}"
When addressing the cultists:  "{@i Loyal servants of Khuzza! Your lord and master requires you to fulfill your oaths!}"

If enticed into sharing the story of how she came to The Living Tower:  "{@i Now that is a tale. I once gazed into a crimson flame. For weeks I slept, and in my dreams, whispers of a true, ancient power offered knowledge beyond that this world could offer. So I sought out this voice, and made my way here. This power I shall not name, but they dwell in the shadows and I would free my true master to stalk this world once more.}"
If enticed into sharing her true motives:  "{@i This cult is but a front. I care little at all for this beast, but it is a useful tool to keep these wretches in line.}"

entries.name: Jouslir
entries: A physically imposing human male, Jouslir was one of the first initiates to the Cult of Khuzza, and remains its most zealous member. None are quite certain of Jouslir's origins and how he came into The Living Tower, for his sacrifice to be inducted into the cult was to remove his own tongue and feed it by hand to Khuzza — the hydra promptly taking his hand in addition to his initial offering.

The mute enforcer communicates with a crude form of sign language, gesturing with his left hand as well as the blade fixed to his right lower arm. Jouslir answers to no one save Veraetis, and even Khuzza appears to view the human with something akin to suspicion, perhaps even respect.

{@b Roleplaying Jouslir.} Despite his loyalty to Veraetis, Jouslir does not suspect her true loyalty lies with the demon, Raz'Drexin. Jouslir is fully devoted to Khuzza and will protect the hydra at all costs. He is cruel and calculating, using fear and the threat of force to ensure the cultists are kept firmly in line. He can be portrayed as follows:

items: - When asked about Khuzza: The hulking human before you gestures to the hydra and bows to it, eyes gazing longingly at the beast. In return, each of the hydra's heads turn to Jouslir, and for a moment you swear that each of the heads nearly bob back slightly in acknowledgement.
- When dealing with the cultists: Jouslir brandishes his right limb menacingly at one of the cultists — and each of them sink to the floor, groveling before the enforcer.
- When interacting with Veraetis: Jouslir stands to the side at attention, head straight, and acknowledging the presence and leadership of the tall woman before him.

entries: Most mortals cower before such an impressive warrior. 〄

entries.name: Khuzza, the Everfeeding Serpent
entries: A massive, five-headed hydra with pale green scales that resemble ash-covered foliage, Khuzza dwells within a deep swamp-like pool within this floor. Having grown to an enormous size, Khuzza is particularly fond of the flesh of humanoid visitors to this floor, having consumed the deceased former denizens of the once swamp-like region where The Living Tower now stands. Despite the creature's fondness for meat, based on the numerous scars and scorch marks upon its scaled hide, its prey (or visitors to Khuzza's floor) will often put up a good fight before being ripped asunder and consumed.

Each of Khuzza's heads are distinctly dragon-like, with jaws lined with razor-sharp teeth and large enough to swallow a Small creature whole or a Medium-sized creature in but a few quick bites. Its heads move independently of one another, yet in a highly coordinated, smooth, snake-like fashion before darting forward with blinding speed to strike.

Khuzza is ravenous at all times, but does not willingly leave the central swampy pool in which the hydra resides. Any creatures within sight are tracked by at least one head, its pale blue eyes tracking movement and clearly ascertaining the likelihood of a meal. If a creature is unfortunate enough to be dragged toward the pool in the jaws of one head, the others will in turn squabble amongst each other for additional scraps, making for a particularly gruesome sight for others to behold.

entries.name: Artuk
entries: One of two remaining members of a band of adventurers along with Tiarsus Tralee, Artuk the Fearless — as he is called among his friends, is a hulking, well-muscled half-orc with a strict code of ethics.

Having been frequently regarded with suspicion from other humanoids for all his life, Artuk greatly preferred living in the wilderness, where his deeds were judged rather than his appearance as opposed to larger cities where some might view him more judgmentally. While living in a remote village working as a blacksmith he decided to join with Tiarsus Tralee and her band, finding his strength of arms more than welcome.

Artuk is muscled and massively strong, the tone of his skin just hinting at his orcish blood. Few are in question of his orcish heritage, however, on those few occasions he might break into a smile (more of a grimace to others), bearing his enlarged canines. Such occasions are seldom. However, as Artuk is suspicious and has little sense of humor.

A half-orc of few words, Artuk is fiercely loyal to Tiarsus, the last remaining member of their group. He isn't particularly insightful, nor will Artuk ever be renowned for his ability to carry a conversation, but he was often the first to lead a charge against raiders or to volunteer to spend hours building a wooden palisade to defend a settlement. He is blunt, honest, and relies on those he trusts who are more clever to guide him. He particularly dislikes orcs who choose a raider's path, so coming across orc-made arrows in a pillaged village before entering The Living Tower hit a particularly sore spot for him.

{@b Roleplaying Artuk.} Being a half-orc as well as a former blacksmith, Artuk never received a formal education. As a result, he speaks only when necessary, often only grunting in acknowledgement. He is intensely angry at being imprisoned and seeing his former companions ripped apart by Khuzza, and would like nothing more than a chance to meet Veraetis, Jouslir, and the members of the cult of Khuzza within arm's reach. He can be portrayed as follows:

items: - When greeting new prisoners (grunting):  "{@i Newcomers. Welcome to dinner. You're about to be served.}"
- When describing how he and his group came to The Living Tower:  "{@i Tracked a bunch of raiders. Orc-made arrows all over. Tracked them. Entered the tower looking for them. Found ourselves here.}"
- When describing the cult of Khuzza:  "{@i They fed the others to that beast. I look forward to being next. I need to wring its necks.}"

entries.name: Tiarsus Tralee
entries: Tiarsus Tralee is a female half-elf prisoner of the Cult of Khuzza. A curious and inquisitive ranger, Tiarsus has spent the last several years with a band of adventurers, aiding remote settlements and steadholts in establishing their presence in frontier regions of the world. She, along with Artuk, are the only remnants of this adventuring band, who were drawn to The Living Tower after seeing the decimated remains of one such nearby steadholt. After tracking what appeared to be several bands of humanoid tracks to The Living Tower, they were offered the opportunity to bring those perpetrators of such a crime to justice in exchange for a test of their mettle.

Tiarsus is clever, observant, and patient. She is quite skilled in the use of both blade and bow, and it was she who tracked the faint traces of humanoid creatures passage through the wasteland near The Living Tower. Tiarsus is an altruistic and positive person by nature, believing in helping others wherever possible and in the impact that any good deed, no matter how small, can have a large influence. Admittedly, her positivity is more than a little shaken since coming to this floor, where she has witnessed her companions sacrificed to Khuzza one by one until only she and Artuk remain.

{@b Roleplaying Tiarsus Tralee.} Normally positive and upbeat, Tiarsus has witnessed her boon companions ripped asunder by Khuzza in particularly gruesome scenes. She has realized it is highly unlikely she and Artuk will be leaving The Living Tower alive, and seems resigned to her fate — at least unless given a reason to hope once again. She may use her {@i animal friendship} spell to entice a rat living within this floor to convey messages to other prisoners. She can be portrayed as follows:

items: When asked about how she and Artuk came to The Living Tower: "We were exploring along the frontier, offering aid to newly established steadholts. We came across one that had been razed, and tracked several bands across a barren wasteland, hoping to come across survivors and bring the perpetrators to justice when we came across this tower. We were offered the opportunity to bring justice to those who performed such a crime, but were told first we had to be tested...and here we are, failing that test."

When describing her companions:  "{@i There were six of us — Thulrik, Gren, Aoife, and Jennera were all sacrificed by this accursed cult. Only Artuk and I remain. Fate has caught up with us it seems.}"

When describing the cult of Khuzza:  "{@i It seems that they are led by the cowled one — she seems more than a little insane. Then there is the warrior...I might have caught his name, Jouslir I think. They are obsessed with that monstrosity!}"
If a plan to escape is discussed, a glimmer of hope comes into her eye:  "{@i A plan...could there be any hope to escape this wretched place? I'd rather not become a snack for that beast...}"

entries.name: Cult of Khuzza (Cultists)
entries: The Cult of Khuzza is composed of a number of visitors to this floor who have pledged themselves to the worship of Khuzza. Former prisoners themselves, to demonstrate their loyalty each new member of the cult is required to sacrifice a part of themselves to Khuzza — some choosing to sever an ear, hand, or even a leg in some cases and feed it by hand to the ravenous Khuzza. In exchange for this demonstration of loyalty, the cultists are allowed access to the meager resources scrounge by Veraetis and Jouslir - some semblance of safety in the presence of a perpetually hungry hydra.

The cultists are loyal to Veraetis, kept in line by the sheer terror induced by the presence of Jouslir, Veraetis' enforcer. In the absence of a powerful presence, their fear may however turn to desperate hope to escape this floor.

{@b Roleplaying the Cult of Khuzza.} Members of the cult seldom speak, and then only to utter guttural prayers directed at Khuzza, or to praise Veraetis. Those few occasions they might speak to a character, they can be portrayed as fearful, only offering the following:   "{@i I belong to Khuzza, they have tasted my flesh. I wish it were not so, I would flee if I could. Help us!}"

entries.name: 1. Teleportation Glyph

entries: You begin to regain consciousness from what appears to have been a rather pleasant dream of flying, suddenly replaced by the distinct sensation of falling. This sensation is correct, as you open your eyes and are shocked to see yourself falling rapidly towards a pool of murky green water.

Compounding your horror as you plummet down toward the pool, the water begins to roil and churn, before a series of  five massive, pale green lizard-like maws erupt from within, reaching up towards you with mouth wide as you hurtle toward it; the creature’s pale blue eyes gazing greedily.

Falling to your doom, about to be swallowed by this great beast, you glance at your surroundings looking for a way out of what appears to be an inevitable rending of your flesh by the teeth of the monstrosity below. Your eyes meet a young woman standing on the shoreline before the pool. You hear a series of words bellowed as she casts an incantation. The next sensation you feel is a chill through your bones before being teleported and slammed onto a damp pile of rotting debris upon a stone floor.

After being teleported by The Living Tower to this floor just above Khuzza's tepid pool for a bit of excitement, the adventurers are then harshly teleported, each into a random cell along the perimeter of this floor by Veraetis. Each adventurer must make a {@b {@dc 17} Dexterity} saving throw, taking 17 (5d6) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half on a successful one. In addition to any bludgeoning damage they take, each adventurer is knocked unconscious for 1 hour.

Nothing instills fear like being helplessly teleported above the gaping maw of this gluttonous beast! Veraetis must feel you are worthy of further investigation, as I've seen her simply let folks plummet down into the beast's belly.  〄

Upon waking, the characters will find themselves each separated into one of nine rooms at the GM’s discretion (Areas 2 - 10). The room at 8 o'clock (Area 8) holds Artuk and the room at 11 o'clock (Area 5) holds Tiarsus Tralee. Both have each been digging short tunnels through weakened stone and soil that comprise their cell floor. Artuk is digging towards Area 7 and Tiarsus is digging towards Area 2. They work hastily, but stop when the guards make their rounds.
As the characters get their bearings, read the following:

You come to your senses with the distinct impression of a lump growing on the side of your head from where it is connected with a hard floor. Disoriented and somewhat groggy from the blow, you find yourself in a small, irregular room that resembles a crudely constructed cave.

To your surprise, the floor is covered in an abundance of vegetation. Mosses, ferns, and other tropical plants grow in abundance around you and up the cave walls. Some species appear to be giving off a faint luminescence.

The air is humid and tropical, and the faint dripping of water from condensation against the cooler stone into pools below can be heard. You sit up and take stock of your surroundings. You realize you are now alone and your gear is missing.

Allow the adventurers to take stock of their surroundings and explore their cells. Read each cell description that is occupied by an adventurer. While unconscious, their weapons, backpacks, armor, and belongings have been stripped from them by Jouslir and the cultists. If they approach the bars to their cell, read the following:

The entrance to your cave — or perhaps cell would be a better description — is barred by a set of sturdy iron bars embedded into the stone floor. A small door, an iron lock affixed, would allow access to the cave outside. The iron is red with rust, no doubt from constant exposure to the humidity within this area that has soaked your shirt already in your short time within this floor.

Looking through the bars, you see a massive, multi-headed reptilian creature emerge from a large pool filled with brackish, tepid green water perhaps 70 feet in diameter. One of several heads swings toward you, its pale blue eyes familiar from your plummet toward what seemed a certain death — and they seem more than disappointed to not have made a meal of you. Outside the pool is an abundance of life - vibrant flowers and ferns the like you have never beheld provide a brilliant spectacle, some emitting a bright luminescence that illuminates the room. Species beyond count line the walls of a central cavern perhaps 120 feet across. Some of the ferns have grown to enormous size, nearly 10 feet across and 15 feet high.
As you wonder at both the monstrous inhabitant of the pool and the unique species surrounding it, the shuffle of footsteps draws your gaze as well as that of each of the creature's five heads.

At this time, {@b Jouslir} begins making his rounds, checking on each of the newcomers in a counterclockwise direction starting at the 5 o'clock position (Area 11). He will gaze stonily at each of the prisoners, determining their condition, but not engage except perhaps to gesture with his bladed arm toward the back of the cell as he ensures the lock to each cell is sturdy. As he makes his rounds, read the following:

You see a muscular human leave the area to the south east and begin approaching the cell directly to the north. The man, who you would correctly assume to be your jailor, is branded with a green symbol on his right pec. The tattoo created with dye no doubt made one of the many species of plants within this floor. His dominating presence is further enhanced by the fact that his eyes faintly glow with a green hue and one of his arms has been replaced with a meticulously polished crude blade; a care in stark contrast to the bars of your cell.
Any attempts to engage with this human are met with silence and a gesture toward the back of your cell with his bladed arm.

As the man makes his way to each of the cells, you watch as the massive reptilian heads of the creature inhabiting the pool follow his movements carefully, but the creature makes no movement toward the shore even though the human seems within reach of its jaws. For his part, your jailer appears unconcerned with the beast's presence.
A {@b {@dc 15} Wisdom (Perception)} check reveals that the jailor occasionally meets the creature's watchful gaze with a slight nod as he departs one cell’s gate for the next.

Should an adventurer shout out loudly at Jouslir, they are met by a series of roars from each of the five heads of Khuzza and confronted with an angered Jouslir who gestures for the character to be silent, opening his mouth and pointing to his removed tongue...then to the hydra.

Below are the descriptions of each cell around the perimeter of this floor. You can read these to the characters after they awaken from their unconsciousness when they are initially placed in their cell.

entries.name: 2. 1 O'clock Cell

entries: You awaken in a tangle of thick vegetation that covers the sandy floor of this cell. Rusted, but apparently sturdy, iron bars enclose this 25-foot by 10-foot cell that slopes down to either side into pools of murky, stinking water. Moss covers the walls. The rusted remnants of two sets of chains embedded in the wall dangle down into one of the pools.

Within the larger pool (5 feet deep), the chains are attached to a set of manacles submerged within. A character exploring the pool will discover the rotten remains of one humanoid arm still entrapped in one of the manacles, though the rest of the body is missing.

The smaller pool slopes sharply toward a narrow end, and a successful {@b {@dc 13} Intelligence (Investigation)} check by a character submerging themselves in this 10-foot-deep pool will indicate the presence of a small tunnel leading to the 11 o'clock cell (holding Tiarsus Tralee. A character must make a successful {@b {@dc 10} Strength (Athletics)} check to swim through the narrow tunnel without getting trapped. A trapped character must make a successful {@b {@dc 12} Strength (Athletics)} check to break free. If the character is underwater for more than 1 minute, they must make a successful Constitution saving throw or fall unconscious. If the character remains unconscious for a number of rounds equal to their Constitution modifier (minimum 1 round), they must make a death saving throw each round until either they are removed from the water or die.

The cell bars are sturdy and rusted, and can be forced open with a successful {@b {@dc 20} Strength (Athletics)} check. On either failure or success, the noise will alert Khuzza, and after 1d4 rounds Jouslir and 1d4 cultists will respond, subduing the culprit(s), knocking them unconscious, and repairing the cell walls.

The locked door can be opened with a successful {@b {@dc 15} Dexterity (Sleight of Hand)} check using a pick fashioned from the iron manacles or bone from the humanoid arm. If picked, a successful {@b {@dc 11} Dexterity (Stealth)} check is required to silently open the rusted door without alerting Jouslir and the cultists.

entries.name: 3. 2 O'clock Cell

entries: The walls and floor of this rather spacious 30-foot by 30-foot cell is covered in a thick layer of moss. Shallow pools of water have collected in the corners of this cell and the stench of decaying plant material offends your nose.
A set of thick iron bars with a locked door made of the same is covered in vines, through which you can see an abundance of brightly colored flora.

The cell bars can be forced open per the description in the 1 o'clock cell, though there are no materials in this room with which to craft a pick. Other than the pools within this cell being filled with decaying vegetation that emits a particularly foul smell if disturbed, this cell is unremarkable.

entries.name: 4. 3 O'clock Cell

entries: This cell is nearly filled with fetid water; only the area near the iron bars enclosing the cell remains somewhat dry. Two sets of manacles contain the decaying remains of a pair of humanoids restrained by a set of manacles embedded in the wall, their legs submerged within the pool. The pool itself is oddly still, but for the occasional drip of water from the condensation dripping down from the ceiling above.

The pool in this room is home to a {@b Swarm of Mutated Quippers}, hence why the skeletal remains within the pool remain undisturbed. The quippers are ravenous, having been trapped in the pool for some time, and will attack and devour any creature that sets foot in the 10-foot deep pool.
The cell bars can be forced open per the description in the 1 o'clock cell, and the cell door picked per the description in the same section.
Should the swarm of mutated quippers be defeated, the pool contains an assortment of coins worth 35 gp, an additional set of manacles, and a rusted longsword in the far corner of the pool.

entries.name: 5. 11 O'clock Cell
entries: This cell holds Tiarsus Tralee, who has been held captive for several days and has attempted to pick the lock unsuccessfully several times. She is aware of the submerged tunnel to the 1 o'clock cell, which she can use to make contact with a character in that cell.

This cell has been somewhat tidied of the rapidly growing vegetation within. The scattered and desperate attempts at crafting items that may be used for escape - a twisted rope made of the thick vines and an attempt at sharpening a shiv from a hardened root - are concealed within the vegetation.
The cell bars can be forced open per the description in the 1 o'clock cell, though there are no materials in this room with which to craft a pick.

entries.name: 6. 10 O'clock Cell

entries: Moss, vines, and the occasional fern cover the sandy loam floor of this 20-foot by 20-foot cell. Two pools of fetid water filled with decaying vegetation lie at the edges of the room, and through rusted iron bars you see a series of large, brightly colored flowering plants beyond which you see the edges of a large pool in a central chamber.
Two sets of rusting manacles are found in the 10-foot-deep pools. Aside from a few random bones, there is nothing else of interest in this cell.
The cell bars can be forced open per the description in the 1 o'clock cell, and the cell door picked per the description in the same section.

entries.name: 7. 9 o'clock Cell

entries: A pair of tepid pools are connected by a patch of soggy, water-laden loam at the edge of this cell. Through the iron bars you have a clear view of a large pool, in which the massive multi-headed beast who so nearly made a meal of you wanders about, its heads searching among the weeds for a morsel or two - almost seeming to be slightly disappointed with the outcome.

A set of rusting manacles lies at the bottom of the larger pool, which is 5 feet deep, and is connected to the 8 o'clock cell containing Artuk. This tunnel has collapsed, however, a character standing in the water notices a slight current leading toward the 8 o'clock tunnel with a successful {@b {@dc 13} Wisdom (Perception)} check. The tunnel can be unblocked with one hour of effort, and a character can crawl through before emerging into the 8 o'clock cell, which is also blocked in the same manner.
The cell bars can be forced open per the description in the 1 o'clock cell, and the cell door picked per the description in the same section.

entries.name: 8. 8 o'clock Cell
entries: This cell holds Artuk, who has been causing a significant ruckus. Several large bruises are clear on his head — despite repeated efforts by Jouslir and the cultists to subdue him, Artuk is relentless in his efforts to force the cell door open.

This cell has clearly been ransacked, any potential avenue for escape explored by its perpetually restless and impatient inhabitant. A set of rusted iron chains is wrapped around the cell doors, vegetation pulled up, holes dug in the loamy earth.
The cell bars can be forced open per the description in the 1 o'clock cell, and the cell door picked per the description in the same section.

entries.name: 9. 7 o'clock Cell

entries: Vines and vegetation weave their way through the iron bars that hold the inhabitants of this cell. The ceiling of this cell is somewhat low, perhaps only 7 feet tall, and it narrows at one end where clearly some of its former inhabitants desperately attempted to dig their way out.

The cell bars can be forced open per the description in the 1 o'clock cell, and the cell door picked per the description in the same section. Two sets of manacles are submerged within 2 or so feet of water. There is evidence that former prisoners in this cell may have attempted to dig their way to the 8 o'clock cell currently containing Artuk, and at the GM's discretion a character may be able to dig their way to this cell given enough time and effort.

entries.name: 10. 6 o'clock Cell

entries: This cell has clearly not been used for a significant length of time. It is heavily overgrown with vines and other vegetation.

The cell bars can be forced open per the description in the 1 o'clock cell, and the cell door picked per the description in the same section. Other than a rusty set of manacles within the submerged section of this cell, there is nothing of significant interest.

entries.name: 11. Cultists Corner

entries: The cultists have clearly made the most isolated corner of this cavern-like floor their headquarters, for it is the furthest from the central pool which is claimed by the massive beast that dwells within. A cooking fire, bedrolls, and other evidence of habitation is found in this area. Clearly the cultists are fighting a losing battle against the quick-growing tropical plants, for vines and tendrils are intertwined throughout everything. A crudely constructed altar bears bloodstains and rusted tools such as knives and hammers - close enough to the pool to entice the beast within.

This area is home to {@b five cultists}, {@b Jouslir} and {@b Veraetis}. Veraetis seldom leaves the relative safety of this corner of the floor — preferring instead to send Jouslir and the cultists to do her bidding. Other than common goods found in any number of camps, there is nothing of interest within this area except for the gear collected from the characters.

entries.name: 12. Khuzza's Pool

entries: A pool that is teeming with life in the form of countless water-dwelling plants and algae is clearly home to the massive multi-headed beast that so nearly devoured you upon your arrival within this floor. Several large and brightly colored plants the likes of which you have never before seen grow either near the edges of the pool or along the rocky perimeter walls. Each species of plant appears to give off a unique glow, illuminating the central chamber in violet and turquoise hues.

The massive hydra has settled within the center of the pool. At times, several of its heads appear to rest, eyes closed while at least one remains alert to any sudden movement, eyes greedily and eagerly searching for its next meal.

Should any creature approach within 5 feet of the pool's edge, {@b Khuzza} will immediately lunge forward and attempt to consume that being. Khuzza makes all initiative rolls with advantage. The pool itself is approximately 20 feet deep and filled with algae, slime, and the occasional hydra dung pile.

The fronds and vegetation are unique — a successful {@b {@dc 17} Intelligence (Nature)} check suggests that the plants that line the perimeter of the pool are ancestors of more modern species, but are themselves uniquely adapted to a low light environment. The two most commonly found colors of plant — violet and turquoise — are complimentary, giving off light that each other can use as a source of energy for photosynthesis. These plants are quite poisonous — any creature consuming them must make a successful {@b {@dc 17} Constitution} saving throw, taking 27 (6d8) poison damage on a failed save or half as much on a successful one. If a creature fails its save by 5 or more, they also fall unconscious; regardless of the outcome of the saving throw, a poisoned creature also makes attack rolls and saving throws with disadvantage until they complete a long rest.

Khuzza will not venture forth from the pool unless provoked or unbearably hungry, preferring the comfort and safety of the pool that also supports the beast's massive bulk. At the bottom of the pool lies the teleportation glyph that both allows access to this floor (from above) or escape. If Khuzza is slain or exits the pool, it will roil and churn with the magical symbols from the glyph, which glow through the algal growth within the pool.
It fascinates me how some mortals can so easily give away their free will to the whims of others. This was what we sought to prevent in the first place... 〄

Once the characters have taken in their surroundings, consider having Veraetis stand at the entrance to the cultist's corner, and either offer an unknown humanoid for sacrifice, or initiate one of the cultists fully into the cult by offering sacrifice to Khuzza:

A figure cloaked in dark gray and bearing an ornate ceremonial staff slowly walks to a point 15 feet from the central pool. Beside her, a figure trembling in fear, but nonetheless standing on their own, bows in reverence to the pool. A powerful voice cracks out, reverberating against the cavern walls:  "{@i Loyal servants of the last hydra, bear witness! Today we welcome another to the worship  of the most powerful of beasts, descendant of dragonkind! Praise be to Khuzza, the devourer, the insatiable, the benevolent!}"
Several additional figures echo the figures final words  "{@i Praise be to Khuzza, the devourer!}" to various degrees of reverence — some trembling, half-hearted; others with vim and vehemence.

With those words, the figure beside the cloaked being casts off their robes, and steps within 10 feet of the pool. The cloaked one whispers in the ear of the now naked male figure, who trembles but holds out an arm. The ravenous anticipation from the beast within the pool is nearly tangible as the cloaked leader whips out a short blade, and with the same fluid motion slices the arm of the male clean off at the elbow.

The figure cries out and collapses in pain, blood spurting violently from the now severed limb. After a brief moment they rise, using their remaining hand to pick up the severed limb and hold it toward the pool.

With a series of ear-splitting roars, the multi-headed beast within the pool rushes forward toward the offering, jaws snapping shut around the bloody arm. Such a monstrous beast could hardly be satisfied by such a meager offering, and the heads snap forward greedily toward the male, who promptly retreats back toward the safety of the rocky walls of the cavern.
Disappointed, the beast's heads snap and snarl at each other, sniffing the ground near the pool for any shred of flesh before reluctantly settling back into the pool.
As the beast sulks back into the water, you catch a glimpse of some familiar runes, faintly glowing within the algae-infested water of the pool, which fade as the hydra returns to its lair.

entries.name: Completing This Floor
entries: This floor may be completed only by accessing the teleportation glyph within the bottom of Khuzza's pool. This may be accomplished by one of two ways: either by defeating Khuzza or by luring the creature out of the pool, which activates the teleportation glyph within.
At the GM's discretion, there are several options for initiating a jailbreak:

items: - A character can bend the bars of their cell with a successful {@b {@dc 17} Strength (Athletics)} check;
- Artuk can break down the bars of his cell, and hold off the cultists while others are freed from their cells;
- A random cultist may choose to smuggle weapons to one or more of the characters, while also offering a keyring that opens the cells;

- Veraetis will sacrifice one of the previous floor's NPCs that is still accompanying the adventuring party, or either Artuk or Tiarsus Tralee, distracting Khuzza and allowing characters to pick or break down their locked cell doors and free others;
- Characters may opt for a stealth-based approach; alluding the attention of Khuzza, retrieve the party's weapons, and facilitate an escape;
- The cultists may be convinced to turn on Jouslir and Veraetis;
- Khuzza may attack a careless cultist who strays too close to the pool, providing an opening to the characters.

entries: Regardless of how Veraetis, Jouslir, the cultists, and Khuzza are defeated, once the teleportation glyph is activated, read or paraphrase the following:
The pool of water is surprisingly warm, yet stinks of algae and excrement. No doubt the stink of hydra dung will take more than a fortnight to remove from your clothing.

Despite the stink, the hum and whir of magical energies is more than welcome to your senses - your senses escape you and you fall into unconsciousness knowing that, if nothing else, you have survived another encounter within The Living Tower, and at least you will not find your way to the next life from a pile of hydra excrement.

entries.name: Background
entries: An ancient primordial creature whose vast memory extends prior to the coming of the gods, prior to the Great Cataclysm, and even to another Plane of existence, Acythylass the Ancient is a creature of great knowledge and wisdom that once lived...elsewhere.

Prior to coming to this world, Acythylass was part of a civilization that enslaved countless beings and consumed the minds of countless more. Seeing the deepest fears and fondest wishes of those they consumed only made Acythylass thirst for more, and as such, the creature developed a reputation for being the most cruel and ruthless of their kind.

All was well in Acythylass' cruel and blood-soaked world — until the true gods arrived and destroyed all that their civilization had built. The survivors of the once-glorious empire scattered, among them Acythylass, who fled deeper and deeper into the Abyss.

By sheer happenstance, Acythylass came upon an underwater portal to a different realm. Fearing for their life at the hands of those that others would deem the true gods, Acythylass fled within the portal, emerging into a new world, one whose depths were filled with all manner of creatures yet untouched by the malevolent presence of the aboleths. Thus Acythylass had at last found the perfect refuge from which to reconstruct a new empire, one of their own imagination, which they could rule over without interference from those filthy self-proclaimed gods — or so they thought.

While this new world was untouched and ripe for conquest; it was also wild and savage. Creatures of the depths unseen and unencountered by Acythylass, their ancestors, or those whose minds they consumed lurked in the great abyssal depths of this new world.

Aiming to conquer and remold this new world in their own image, Acythylass quickly began to amass an unerringly loyal following. Over centuries, Acythylass, now known as the Ancient One to their subjects, began to construct a new and vast empire beneath the waves — that is, until the seas boiled with fury the likes Acythylass had never before encountered.

Rockslides decimated the depths. Maelstroms consumed Acythylass' progeny. Tidal waves cast their followers ashore to perish in the dry overworld. Once again, Acythylass fled, seeking the safety of a vast underground cavern system that eventually led into the depths of a newly constructed tower.

This tower was unlike any others, for using their vast telepathic powers, Acythylass was able to touch an element of the consciousness of a being of vast power, one who seemed of a similar essence to the so-called gods that had once overthrown Acythylass' former civilization. This essence identified itself as Karthax.

Sensing an opportunity to both regain their former strength, Acythylass settled within the tower and began to engage in an unending battle of wits with Karthax. Acythylass spawned more progeny once again, summoned the pitiful remnants of their following, and began to learn what they could from the god. Acythylass could sense the time of the gods might soon be at an end...

entries.name: Author's Vision
entries: The final level of The Living Tower sees adventurers teleported to its foundation, which is so deep that it taps into an underground aquifer system beneath the wastelands upon which The Living Tower sits. Within dwells Acythylass the Ancient as well as Greylythoon, their identical but physically smaller progeny who has taken a new name. They, along with their servitors and cecaelia minions are the inhabitants of this floor, and are able to come and go as they please through these tunnels.

Being immensely powerful while in their lair, we envision Achythylass and Greylythoon as initially merely observing the adventurer's actions at first, determining their threat or potential as servitors. Being both cruel and highly intelligent, they are likely to toy with their prey before dispatching it with a minimum of effort and consuming the minds of their victims.

Having consumed the minds of countless other beings who eventually made their way to this floor, both Acythylass and Greylythoon have detailed knowledge of The Living Tower as well as each of its denizens. Whether they share that knowledge or even see fit to discuss it is of another matter.

Both creatures are motivated by a single purpose, to reconstruct their great empire once more. To do so they require a workforce, and as such will be more inclined to enslave than to outright kill visitors to their lair.
We have included several potential suggested dynamics to add an element of challenge to this floor:

items: There is a strong current from an underground river that flows through this floor. It makes several areas difficult to traverse, and may result in adventurers becoming separated from each other. If separated, it may provide an excellent opportunity for either Acythylass or Greylythoon to attack, subdue, or enslave loners.
Acythylass may choose to project an illusion of themselves to goad or otherwise engage the adventurers, perhaps enticing them onward.

The dynamic between Acythylass and Karthax might be an interesting one — being arrogant, Acythylass or Greylythoon may be inclined to monologue about their opposing views compared to Karthax — that is, enslavement and subjugation as opposed to free will.

The mucus coating of Acythylass and Greylythoon, while causing a disease that prevents a creature from being out of water for a prolonged period of time, is also the means by which adventurers escape The Living Tower via another underground river that eventually flows to the sea (see the Epilogue section).

Underwater combat may prove difficult for characters — yet defeating Acythylass and Greylythoon is not required to escape The Living Tower, for characters may still escape via the underwater cavern system beneath The Living Tower.

entries.name: Acythylass, the Ancient
entries: The ancient primordial creature known as Acythylass has lived for many millennia, in both this world and others. Despite their nearly impeccable memory, even such distant times are difficult to recollect, for few beings could possibly imagine the troves of knowledge lurking within their mind, never mind comprehending the meanings of such knowledge.

For the sake of the pitiful mortal beings that call this world home, suffice to say that Acythylass the Ancient, was once a powerful overlord in another world. The Ancient and their brethren were responsible for the enslavement of countless beings, and as a cruel and merciless ruler directed the construction of a great underwater civilization that spanned the ocean. Their rule was absolute, until the true gods (or were they god-like beings?) arrived in their world. In their self-righteous ways these beings waged a great war against the primordials, eventually triumphing over the ancient ones and driving the few that remained into the depths.

Seething in impotent rage, Acythylass fled along with the remnants of their once-glorious — and blood-soaked — civilization. The primordial beings, reduced to bickering amongst themselves and vying for supremacy, scattered across the seas. Alone, Acythylass came to an underwater maelstrom that proved to be an underwater portal to...elsewhere.

Seeing an opportunity to flee this realm and perhaps build a new civilization, more glorious than the last, Acythylass entered the maelstrom, emerging into a sea teeming with an abundance of life the likes they had never before seen.

The primordial set about their task with fervor, conquering the simple-minded underwater denizens of this world with ease, consuming the minds of those who would not bend to their will. Known to their subjects only as the Ancient One, they set about crafting a new underwater empire. More than that, armed with the knowledge of the existence of other worlds, perhaps linked by portals such as the one that brought them here, Acythylass began scheming to conquer not only the seas of this world, but of others as well.

Over several centuries, Acythylass consolidated their power, bred formidable offspring containing the genetic memory of their hermaphroditic parent, and carved out an empire in the northern seas that surface dwellers feared to sail with their flimsy wooden vessels. Those who were bold, foolish, or plain stupid enough to try to traverse these waters quickly met a watery grave. Those who were strong enough to resist the Ancient One's minions were psionically dominated and kept as servitors who would obey their every whim.

While the ongoing events of the surface world seldom concerned Acythylass, as they would later learn an event known as the Great Cataclysm boiled the seas and once again annihilated centuries of effort.

Rockslides buried the newly constructed cities Acythylass' followers had toiled to build. Multiple maelstroms opened and consumed the Ancient One's progeny, their fate unknown. Tidal waves swept all but a pitiful few of Acythylass' followers onto the shore where they perished beneath a withering sun.

Acythylass fled once again, seeking refuge within a complex underwater cavern system beneath the main continent of this world. There, safe from the ravages unleashed by the Great Cataclysm, Acythylass tentatively reached out with their psionic energies, touching the mind of a powerful being that seemed...familiar.

Following this mind, Acythylass came to the foundation of a relatively newly constructed tower, perhaps only a few years old. The Ancient One, wary of the presence of a powerful so-called god, also saw opportunity, for it seemed the god-like presence that identified itself as Karthax was unfamiliar with the primordials.
Likewise, Karthax saw an opportunity engaging with the primordial, for never had they encountered such a strange being whose mind was so foreign to that of the mortal denizens of this world.

The two beings — Ancient One and Eld God — thus began slowly learning about one another, always probing, always debating, always seeking an advantage or secret knowledge the other might possess. Allowing this strange being from elsewhere access at will to the submerged cavern system beneath the wastelands and into The Living Tower suited Karthax well. Not only did the Eld God slowly begin to learn the ways of a being so unlike anything they encountered, but it also provided the Eld God with the opportunity to debate with a highly intelligent being. In exchange, Acythylass was provided with shelter and — unbenownst to Karthax — the opportunity to study, and perhaps even seek vengeance, against one of the self-proclaimed Gods that had ruined the Ancient One's rule so many millennia ago.

{@b Roleplaying Acythylass.} Acythylass is cruel, cunning, and arrogant. However, they are also extremely intelligent and curious, and will engage with adventurers if only to determine if they are a threat. After toying with adventurers for a bit for their own amusement, Acythylass will inevitably grow bored and attempt to separate and enslave them. They view the mortal races as vastly inferior, and meant to be ruled over by force. Acythylass communicates telepathically, in sucking and slurping tones as though someone were trudging through thick mud...or mucus. They can be portrayed as follows:

items: When addressing visitors to their lair:  "{@i So, tasty morsel, how did you get to my domain?}"
When asked about their origins:  "{@i Your mind could not possibly comprehend one iota of my memories... why should I waste precious energy on you when I could simply consume you?}"
When asked about Karthax:  "{@i Ahhhh, yes...the being known as Karthax. What if I told you they were not at all a so-called god? I have encountered their ilk before. Not all that impressive.}"

entries.name: Acythylass' Lair Actions
entries: While inside their lair, Acythylass can invoke the ambient magic to take lair actions. On initiative count 20 (losing initiative ties), Acythylass takes a lair action to cause one of the following effects:

items: Acythylass casts the {@i suggestion} spell (no components required) on any number of creatures it can see within 60 feet of it. While maintaining concentration on this effect, Acythylass can’t take other lair actions. If a target succeeds on the saving throw or if the effect ends for it, the target is immune to this lair action for the next 24 hours, although such a creature can choose to be affected.

Pools of water within 90 feet of Acythylass surge outward in a grasping tide. Any creature on the ground within 20 feet of such a pool must succeed on a {@b {@dc 14} Strength} saving throw or be pulled up to 20 feet into the water and knocked prone. Acythylass can’t use this lair action again until it has used a different one.

Water in Acytyhlass' lair magically becomes a conduit for the creature’s rage. Acythylass can target any number of creatures it can see in such water within 90 feet of it. A target must succeed on a {@b {@dc 14} Wisdom} saving throw or take 7 (2d6) psychic damage. Acythylass can’t use this lair action again until it has used a different one.

entries.name: Lair Effects
entries: The flooded foundation of The Living Tower is warped by Acythylass' presence:

items: The surfaces of this floor are slimy and wet (considered difficult terrain).
The water within this floor is foul and undrinkable, creatures that do so vomit the water 1 minute after ingesting it.
Acythylass can create an illusory image of itself while within this floor per the {@i major image} spell. The illusion is maintained as long as Acythylass maintains concentration.

entries.name: Greylythoon
entries: The newly spawned hermaphroditic offspring of Achythylass, Greylythoon possesses all of their progenitor's knowledge and memories, but is physically developing and thus remains within the safety of the lower level of The Living Tower. It looks extremely similar in appearance to Achythylass, but with different coloring.

entries.name: Fargrim Snuffbottom
entries: A somewhat prickly and grumpy gnomish diviner, Fargrim Sunffbottom comes from a long line of gnomes renowned for their magical abilities — though his family is perhaps even better known for their unique brew of turnip ale. Standing a proud 3 feet 6 inches tall and weighing a healthy 3 stone (42 lbs), Fargrim is both proud and stubborn. Gnomish children in his village would frequently evade Fargrim whenever he would trundle down the streets and alleys with the support of his staff, ducking away from his glare - for he had a fearsome reputation for being impatient and ornery, particularly with children — for the old gnome had little time for shenanigans and pranks.
Yet despite his outward hard exterior and gruffness, the bearded, white-haired old gnome cares deeply about his family, friends, and village — including the children, as well.

While content to run the brewery that had been in his family for several generations, Fargrim would on occasion seek to glimpse into the future. On most occasions but a few fleeting images would come to the gnome; yet on one fateful night, perhaps notable for his testing of a new ale recipe perhaps a bit excessively, a vision as clear as the spring water used in his brews came to Fargrim.

First, Fargrim beheld the sight of a teetering stone tower in a blasted wasteland. He beheld an image of a being of light, so bright and beautiful they nearly blinded him. Reaching out, the being released nine gemstones: four (a pearl, ruby, diamond, and onyx) burned brightly with an inner fire, levitating above the others. One, what appeared to be jade, barely levitated and only hinted at an inner light. Three (a sapphire, emerald, and topaz) remained in the being's hand, clasped tightly. The final gemstone — an ever-changing opal that reflected the being's light into countless colors, levitated apart from the others.

Countless images then rapidly flashed before Fargrim's eyes: of legions of horned, cloven-footed creatures bearing vicious weapons, of great armies clashing. Of bound and chained beings of many races, marching along worn paths into the distance while carrion crows circled above.

Fargrim beheld images of great battles — of strife and conflict. Such visions brought the old gnome to his knees, before he saw the tower once more — illuminated by a ray of light that caused it to crumble and collapse. The last of the premonitions was a telepathic voice reaching out to him: "The time is nigh. In the north, the fate of free will shall be decided."

Head throbbing, Fargrim awoke in a cold sweat from what he had beheld. Determined to prevent the calamities he had just witnessed from coming to pass, that very day the wizard set forth, trusty staff in hand and the adventurer's pack from his father upon his back.

For several months, Fargrim traveled north, always inquiring from the locals if they knew of a crumbling tower in a barren wasteland, yet most simply looked queerly at the gnome — clearly too old for adventuring — as though he was a lunatic. One local, however, told Fargrim of a new mining venture to the north, where gemstones of great value had been discovered. Perhaps there Fargrim might find the answers he sought?
With newfound hope and determination, Fargrim continued onward, his divinations burned into his memories.

Within one of the many taverns set up to quench the thirst of the newly wealthy miners, Fargrim came across a charming adventurer on the same path, who had also heard of the crumbling tower. The stranger accompanied Fargrim into the barrens, where they finally — exhausted, dusty, and with food and water depleted — came to the crumbling tower Fargrim beheld in his vision. Turning to thank his companion, Fargrim was shocked to find he had disappeared with nary a trace.
Entering the tower, Fargrim was immediately addressed by a telepathic voice: "I have been waiting...welcome to my tower! Enter, and you may find the answers you seek..."
Completely alone and armed with only his wits and skills as a wizard, Fargrim entered without hesitation.

His wiles have allowed the lone gnome to outwit many of the foes in The Living Tower — having escaped from Krul'Thunk, the three sisters, as well as Jarl Hjálmŷr before coming to this floor, which Fargrim is just beginning to explore.

{@b Roleplaying Fargrim Snuffbottom.} Fargrim Snuffbottom is an old, stubborn, and cantankerous gnome. While at first he may come across as argumentative, even offensive to some, Fargrim will listen carefully and, should a course of action make sense, relent and eventually help others out. Having been treated poorly whenever he shared his vision, the gnome will reluctantly describe it and his journey to The Living Tower if pressed. Fargrim can be voiced (in an ornery English accent) as follows:

items: When addressing newcomers, with cautious distrust, grumbles:  "{@i Aye...now who might you fools be?}"
When pressed on his journey to The Living Tower:  "{@i Now why would I be of a mind to share that tale with you? Few believed me, why should you?}"

When further pressed:  "{@i How long do ye have? What should I tell ye of — I've seen a two-headed dimwit, three blood-crazed sisters who can't remember anything, and a delusional ice giant...or if those weren't crazy enough, maybe ye'd like to hear about the end of the world?}"

entries.name: 1. Teleportation Glyph

entries: The magical glyphs that have now become so familiar gently place you upon the ground. Unlike previous exposures to Karthax's magic, this time you are only slightly disoriented, and stumble slightly as the glyph upon which you stand becomes silent.

You are greeted by the scent of decay, but not of rot nor decomposing bodies - more the scent of mold and of wet stone. The stonework of the room in which you find yourself appears to be ancient, reminding you perhaps of an underground tomb. The walls are covered in lichen, and you can hear the sound of running water echoing against the walls of the room.
There is nothing of significance in this room. However, the stonework might suggest to a dwarf or someone learned in the ways of masonry that this floor is underground.
A narrow corridor sloping down is partially submerged, first in but a few inches of water before becoming deeper in the next room — perhaps 3 feet deep.

entries.name: 2. Partially Submerged Room

entries: Following the narrow corridor, you trek through water of ever greater depths, coming to a room perhaps 20-feet wide and 35-feet long. You can see several corridors branching off this room - however they appear to curve as opposed to the linear construction so common with most stonemasons. The stone glistens faintly.

Entering the room you feel the tug of a strong current flowing from one side of the room down several corridors. Random debris and half-decayed plant material bobs gently in the current. The smell of decay and must grow noticeably stronger.

The water is 3 feet deep in this room, and the current fed from an underground river (strong enough to prevent a creature from swimming against it) makes it difficult to cross. Adventurers must make a successful {@b {@dc 13} Strength (Athletics)} check to cross to the other side, Small or smaller creatures have disadvantage on the check. If a creature fails its check, it is pushed 5 feet away from the underground river for every 10 feet the creature travels, and if the creature fails its check by 5 or more it loses its footing and is swept randomly down one of the two tunnels opposite the stream.

entries.name: 3. Tunnels

entries: The walls of the tunnels were clearly once masoned by a skilled craftsperson, however they have been worn completely smooth and are covered with a slime that, when touched, feels more akin to a thick mucus that resembles that of a common garden slug.
To say that it smells revolting would be considered an understatement. The water has become noticeably more pungent and foul smelling, similar to a stagnant swamp.

The walls of the tunnel are coated with Acythylass and Greylythoon's slime. While less potent than the mucus on their bodies, creatures must still make a {@b {@dc 12} Constitution} saving throw or become diseased (as described in their stats).

A {@b {@dc 15} Intelligence (Investigation)} check made on the stone (made with advantage by a dwarf) suggests that the stonework has been worn smooth by some great creature's constant movements through the tunnels, and that the odd shape of the tunnels is due to this.
There are several smaller tunnels used by {@b Greylythoon} and the {@b cecaelia} servants to travel through this floor.

entries.name: 4. Fully Submerged Room
entries: This room contains five {@b servitors} who will attack any intruders if Acythylass or Greylythoon command them to do so. Much of the debris within has been pushed against the wall — bits of wood from shipwrecks, the remnants of crates, and other flotsam and jetsam have collected and blocked the passage in the northeastern corner of the room. Several additional tunnels connect this room to the rest of the floor. Read or paraphrase the following:

This room is fully submerged in water, and a strong current constantly pushes you toward what you presume to be the northeastern corner of the wall - though you aren't quite certain. The current has kept this water relatively clear - enough to make out five humanoid figures wearing rusted armor and bearing wickedly barbed harpoons swimming toward you. Their dull eyes are glazed over and unfocused.

The debris blocking the northeastern tunnel can be removed, requiring 10 minutes of toil and a successful {@b {@dc 15} Strength (Athletics)} check. Doing so causes the current to rush through the tunnel behind and into Acythylass' chamber. Characters must succeed on a {@b {@dc 16} Strength} saving throw or be caught in the current.

entries.name: 5. Central Chamber
entries: A small central chamber, higher than the northern part of this floor, has become filled with flotsam and jetsam that has blocked several tunnels:

The small room appears somewhat higher in elevation, for the water level within is perhaps 2 feet. Thick mucus coats every surface, and debris has jammed what appear to be several more tunnels. In one corner stands a stone statue of a vicious-looking lion with the wings of a bat - or perhaps a dragon - and a curved, segmented tail ending in a wickedly barbed stinger poised as though to strike. Its mouth opens in a roar, the statue's ruby eyes seem to follow your every move.

Several tunnels lead out of this room, most descending tunnels that are partially submerged. Descending steps can be seen through the largest opening, where the water has turned from a relatively clear turquoise to a pale green. The water in this direction seems somewhat...thicker. A small shadow can be glimpsed shooting rapidly through the water in this direction.

The statue is that of a manticore, a creature only heard of in legends in this world. Its eyes are carved rubies, each worth 1000 gp. They can be removed with a successful {@b {@dc 15} Dexterity (Sleight of Hand)} check.

entries.name: 6 & 7. Dry Rooms

entries: Passing through the strong current and following a short, partially submerged room, you follow a short series of ascending stairs and come to a small, somewhat dry room - a welcome opportunity to get out of the cold water. Debris litters the floor, what appears to be the remains of at least one ship's planks. In the corner the prow of a ship, including the ship's figurehead has apparently been salvaged. The figurehead itself is a carved, winged humanoid with wings unfurled, gesturing into the distance - though its hand had been snapped off.
There is nothing of significance in the first room. In the second:
The shattered remains of a wooden door, now rotten and its hinges rusted, greet you as you enter a large room measuring perhaps 25 by 40 feet.

You see a small, waterlogged figure covering a skeleton with a tattered cloak, their back turned to you. A gnarled oaken staff lies nearby. Slowly the figure stands to its full height - perhaps 3 and a half feet tall - and groans as they do so. The figure turns toward you. Clearly shocked at the site of others, the white-bearded gnome grabs their staff with surprising agility and points it toward you:  "{@i Aha! Who be ye, and how in the hells did ye sneak up on old Snuffbottom?}"

After his initial shock and after regarding the adventurers with no small amount of suspicion, Fargrim will share his story willingly — though he will be reluctant to share his vision (he will do so with a successful {@b {@dc 16} Charisma (Persuasion)} check).
